DOC.HEAD: The Best Thing To Do: Ray Liotta's Passion for Films
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: At one time Ray Liotta would have been perfectly happy to just stay home. His mother was the movie fan of the family; Liotta preferred sports. He went out for the senior play in high school only after quitting the basketball team because of a fight with his coach. And when Liotta decided to study acting at the University of Miami, he wasn't doing it out of a compulsion to entertain or a need for artistic expression. He simply had nothing better to do. ``My parents wanted me to go to college and I didn't want to go,'' said Liotta, who stars with Robert De Niro and Joe Pesci in ``GoodFellas.'' ``My parents then suggested I take a year off and find out what life's all about. I decided to go to the University of Miami and take drama so I wouldn't have to take a math class. And when I got there, I didn't want to do anything.'' But he changed. Not right away; Liotta had no great desire to act immediately after graduating. But by 1986, when he hustled his way into a small, but memorable role in ``Something Wild,'' the actor was hungry for work. Now, after ``Dominic and Eugene'' and ``Field of Dreams,'' the offers come to him. Liotta didn't have to beg for the starring role of ``GoodFellas.'' He wanted the part and director Martin Scorsese wanted him. Even De Niro put in a good word. The movie runs more than two hours and covers four decades. Liotta is in virtually every scene. ``You have to have a certain amount of confidence to be an actor,'' Liotta said in an interview. ``In this film, I had to show jealousy, rage, happiness, anger . . . everything was there. You want to take that challenge as an actor. It was pretty intense. ``I had 80 costume changes, one day's in the '50s, the next day's in the '80s. Emotionally, it was all different things. One day I'm sweet. Then the next day I'm coked out of my mind. We'd span 20 years at one location.'' ``GoodFellas'' is based on Nicholas Pileggi's best-selling novel, ``Wiseguy.'' Liotta plays Henry Hill, a half-Irish, half-Sicilian Brooklyn kid drawn to the fast-paced gangster life who eventually hooks up with mobsters De Niro and Pesci. Off screen, Liotta had to fit in as well. De Niro and Scorsese have worked many times before, notably in ``Raging Bull'' and ``Taxi Driver.'' Liotta, knowing this was his chance to establish himself as a major star, did his best to treat the film like just another job. ``These guys have made major, major movies. They're considered geniuses and brilliant and all that. I just approached it as a game, just telling a story, no big deal. I read the book about five years ago and thought, `Geez, I could do this.' '' Liotta began acting in soaps shortly after graduating from college. He worked for three years on ``Another World,'' appreciating the steady work and learning how to feel comfortable in front of a camera. But after appearing in the short-lived TV series ``Casablanca'' and ``Our Family Honor,'' he struggled to find work. Having nothing to do wasn't much fun anymore. When Liotta learned there was an opening for a violent ex-con in ``Something Wild,'' he pushed hard, trying unsuccessfully to get an audition and finally calling on his friend, Melanie Griffith, the film's star. ``I said, `Let me phone Melanie'; she was already cast. (Director Jonathan) Demme was down to three guys and it was the final week of casting. She said, `Great idea, I'll do that.' I wish she had thought of that before. I was just so angry about trying to get in and the part called for an angry guy. I went in angry and luckily it worked out.'' He played nice for ``Dominic and Eugene,'' starring as a quiet medical student who takes care of his retarded brother, and was a good guy in ``Field of Dreams,'' appearing as the ghost of baseball great Shoeless Joe Jackson. All his characters are motivated by passion, the actor says. For ``GoodFellas,'' it was the drive for money and power. There was his wife (Griffith) in ``Something Wild,'' his brother in ``Dominic and Eugene'' and baseball in ``Field of Dreams.'' Liotta's own passion came during those frustrating times before ``Something Wild,'' when he and fellow unemployed actors Kevin Costner and Andy Garcia would hang out and try to keep their spirits up, like frustrated minor leaguers just begging for the manager to hand them the ball. ``I didn't have any doubts about my ability,'' Liotta said. ``I wasn't wondering when I was going to get a break. I'm not being cocky, it was tough, no question about it. You see these people, and think, `I can't do that?' I can at least do it as well, and with more commitment.''

DOC.HEAD: Caribbean Back in Business, but Problems Persist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Purple and red bougainvillea are back in bloom, seaside resorts are open and cruise ships call again at most of the dozen Caribbean islands battered by Hurricane Hugo. St. Croix in the U.S. Virgin Islands and the British colony of Montserrat still are rebuilding, but elsewhere there is little remaining evidence of the worst storm in a decade, which killed at least 56 people and caused more than $2 billion in damage on Sept. 17-18, 1989. ``I think we've recovered better than expected,'' said Carl Mitchell, director of the Economic Secretariat of the seven-member Organization of Eastern Caribbean States in St. John's, Antigua. ``Initially, we had looked at the possible long-term effects and had indicated it was going to take three years before there would be full recovery,'' he said. ``But I think this may apply just to Montserrat. The recovery in the other islands has been quite startling.'' Nevertheless, Mitchell said, the hurricane caused a drop in economic growth rates and a sharp rise in the cost of living in Montserrat and the neighboring islands of Antigua, Dominica and St. Kitts-Nevis. On St. Croix, where one-third of the homes were demolished or heavily damaged by winds of up to 200 mph, life is returning to normal gradually. Two insurance companies went out of business, leaving more than $55 million in claims to 1,000 homeowners and 200 businesses unpaid. The territorial government has agreed to cover policyholder losses of up to $100,000 each, but hundreds of families are still waiting to have their homes rebuilt. One million cubic yards of debris has been cleared from the island and restaurants and stores in Christiansted, the main town, are operating. The landscape, once brown from defoliation, is greener now. The Education Department said all but one of the island's 10 schools were reopening for the fall term after repairs made with a $43 million federal grant. Thirty-three cruise ships are to resume port calls in October. Betty Sperber, president of the Hotel and Tourism Association on St. Croix, said 10 of the 15 major hotels would be open by then, but the other five were closing permanently. St. Croix's image as an American paradise suffered both from the hurricane's destruction and four days of looting that followed. President Bush sent 1,100 military police to restore order. They stayed for two months and the island was under curfew. Residents still have angry memories of news reports at the time about marauding gangs of blacks attacking wealthy whites with machetes. Police Chief Delroy Richards says more than 100 people, including some prominent residents, were arrested on theft charges but ``none of the cases can I say were racially motivated.'' ``I feel the looting is behind us,'' he said. ``People have condemned those persons who took items that were not needed.'' St. Croix, population 56,000, was by far the hardest hit of the three main U.S. Virgin Islands. It has received the bulk of $750 million provided to the territory by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, known as FEMA. Hugo also heavily damaged St. Thomas, whose population is about the same; sparsely populated St. John, and the neighboring British Virgin Islands, but all of them recuperated quickly. Puerto Rico, a U.S. commonwealth of 3.6 million people 70 miles west of St. Croix, returned to normal within weeks of the hurricane despite an estimated $1.3 billion in damage and lost production. Jose Bravo, the FEMA coordinator in San Juan, said 900 families still were living in temporary modular housing, mostly in northeastern Puerto Rico and on the offshore islands of Culebra and Vieques. He said FEMA provided $72 million to the commonwealth government for new housing but construction has been delayed by permits, contracts and land development. Only $1.1 million of $14.2 million raised for hurricane victims by a 12-hour simultaneous telethon in San Juan, New York and Miami had been distributed by the end of August, 11 months later. Luis Davila, administrator of the telethon fund, said all applicants should have their money within three months. She said the fund also would build 330 homes, all expected to be ready by Christmas. Montserrat, a small, pear-shaped island with only 12,500 residents 200 miles south of Puerto Rico, was all but flattened by the hurricane and remains far from completely recovered. Reuben Meade, the government's director of development, said about 90 percent of the island's 4,000 homes had been rebuilt and businesses had reopened in Plymouth, the capital. Electricity, water and telephone services have been restored and the two major hotels have reopened, he said, but roads need repairs, the port still uses a barge as its main jetty and little work has been done on government buildings. In Guadeloupe, which has 340,000 inhabitants and was the first island in Hugo's path, wood and corrugated iron is heaped in places and schools and houses still are being rebuilt. Franklin McDonald, director of the Pan-Caribbean Disaster Preparedness and Prevention Project in Antigua, said the French government responded quickly. ``There are still housing repairs being done, but to a great extent Guadeloupe is back to normal,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Warfare? Don't Worry, Just Keep That Mask on Until `All Clear'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: AP Military Writer Susanne Schafer recently traveled to Fort Hood with General Carl Vuono, the Army's chief of staff, where elements of the 1st Cavalry and 2nd Armored Divisions are preparing to ship out to Saudi Arabia. This is the second of three reports.

Staff Sgt. Connie Martens barked out the chemical weapons drill to her two-dozen charges, sweaty young Army soldiers swathed head to toe in thick, green and black protective gear. ``Blister agent ... usually not fatal. Possibility of liquid use. ... We have the M2-58A1. ... Hold your breath, grab your M2-58A1. At that time you will start decontaminating your skin. Once you decontaminate your skin, no problem!'' Martens told her troops in rat-a-tat style. Some 15,000 soldiers from two armored divisions at this sprawling Texas fort will soon trade its rolling hills for the sands of Saudi Arabia. And Iraq's Saddam Hussein might be their next instructor in the dangers of chemical warfare. So the soldiers from the 1st Cavalry Division listened intently to the petite sergeant with the booming voice - a chemical weapons expert with 15 years of service - as they got themselves and their gear ready to deploy. ``Blisters may begin to appear on your skin. ... Don't pop the blisters. If you break the blisters, you have the secondary problem of infection. You don't want infections out there, so just keep 'em covered like you've always been trained, like a normal burn casualty and you won't have a problem. Any questions?'' she asked. ``Yeah, I've got a question,'' a voice sounded from the side of the huddle. ``What's the standard for putting on a protective mask?'' Backs stiffened and eyes widened as a big-shouldered four-star general in jungle green and brown fatigues worked his way to the front of the group. Gen. Carl Vuono, the Army's chief of staff, had come to see whether his troops were getting the proper training before being sent in harm's way. ``Who knows?'' Vuono shouted at the group, soldiers who'd rarely been quizzed by a multistar general, let alone the Army's top commander. ``Nine seconds!'' came a chorused reply. ``So what's the signal?'' Vuono asked. Without waiting for a response, he then boomed out: ``Gas! Gas! Gas!'' Ripping their black headgear from their belts, the soldiers squeezed their eyes shut add held their breath as they struggled to place the heavy goggles and plastic cover over their heads. A few wouldn't have made it in time. Most did. ``Not bad, not bad,'' Vuono said, checking his watch. ``Let's try it again. Put 'em back!'' As a few men started to remove their clumsy headgear, the muffled sound of ``Negative, negative'' emerged from the under the Darth Vader-like hoods. Vuono beamed with delight - the soldiers had refused his order because he'd not given the proper command ``All clear.'' ``Well done! Well done! I tell you, Tilleli, I'm proud of these guys!'' Vuono shouted to their commander, Maj. Gen. John Tilleli Jr., who stood nearby. Leaning on his brown and green cane - the general had recently undergone hip surgery so his staff had covered his hospital-issued yellow cane with camouflage tape - Vuono told the soldiers they were going a long way from Fort Hood, to a place much hotter than Texas. And they also might have to go up against an opponent who has used chemical weapons before. All hoods and goggles were still, trained on the general. ``I don't know whether he'll use them, I don't know whether we'll fight him. All I do know is, I don't want any soldier going to Saudi Arabia that isn't well trained,'' the general said. ``We're damn proud of each and every one of you, and we wish you all the best and Godspeed as you deploy on Desert Shield,'' Vuono said, saluting. ``Good luck. Good job.'' ``Tet-Hup!'' came the command. As Vuono strode away, the rubberized soldiers stood at attention under shade of the scrub oak. Then with the speed of a bullet, Sgt. Martens was spouting her commands again, getting her charges ready to move through the training booth that simulates a chemical weapons attack. ``All right men, move to the next area, move to the CS area. If you have any contacts, make sure you get 'em out. We don't want to make you cry. Just a safety precaution, get 'em out.''

DOC.HEAD: Johnston: Duke `Clear and Present Danger' to Louisiana
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Sen. J. Bennett Johnson is billing himself as a Washington insider who delivers for Louisiana in his bid to avert a November runoff against former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke. On the campaign trail, Johnston paints a dark picture of a freshman Duke in Washington. He warns that electing the ex-Klansman to the U.S. Senate could cost Louisiana military bases and other government projects. ``We're not talking about a debating contest in Washington,'' Johnston said at a recent campaign rally. ``We're talking about the future of central Louisiana. We don't need to be growing hate here in Louisiana.'' At stake, he says, is the future of England Air Force Base and Fort Polk, two major military installations in central Louisiana, as well as the Red River navigation project, a proposal that has been pending since the 1970s. Johnston, who chairs the Senate Energy Committee and sits on the budget committee, says he has the congressional clout that comes from seniority. The three-term senator is in no danger of losing his seat. But still in question is whether the incumbent will win another term outright in the state's open primary on Oct. 6. If no candidate wins 50 percent, the top two vote-getters face off in a November runoff. In one recent poll, 48 percent of the voters favored Johnston and 28 percent backed the maverick Republican Duke. Eleven percent supported state Sen. Ben Bagert, according to the survey by Mason-Dixon Opinion Research. Bagert is the GOP's endorsed candidate but he has lagged far behind Johnston and Duke throughout the campaign. The poll showed Duke and Johnston running even among white voters, but gave Johnston a commanding lead among blacks. Johnston said Duke garners support because ``it gives people a way to vote against every Jesse Jackson and every black on a town council.'' He warns that a monthlong runoff campaign would further embarrass Louisiana and erode the state's chances for attracting industry and saving its federal projects. ``Can you imagine that we're going to keep England Air Force Base if David Duke is elected to the U.S. Senate?'' Johnston asks on the campaign trail. ``When you don't have much seniority, you don't have much clout.'' Johnston takes credit for keeping alive the Red River project despite opposition from presidents Carter and Reagan and so far during the Bush administration. ``That's what seniority can do for you. I can get it done,'' he said. Both Democratic and Republican opponents have debated how best to handle Duke. When Duke ran for a vacant seat in the Louisiana House in 1989, his opponent, John Treen, drew the endorsement of President Reagan and the Republican Party. Amid high media attention, Duke won the seat. When Johnston began a recent campaign swing in Baton Rouge, he said he was on as a ``crusade'' but did not mention Duke by name. Within a week, however, Johnston was waging counterattacks against Duke - who delights in calling the incumbent ``J. Benedict Johnston.'' Johnston says Duke ``is Hollywood handsome. He is a good persuader as most con men are.'' Duke, meanwhile, maintains he has put his Klan and neo-Nazi past behind him. ``I was intolerant. I'm ashamed of that,'' Duke has said. He is the head of the National Association for the Advancement of White People. In campaign appearances, he rails against welfare cheats and affirmative action. Duke accuses Johnston of using ``scare tactics'' and says the senator's claim that Louisiana could lose federal projects if he is electd is ``ridiculous.'' ``We have a better chance of keeping military bases with a Republican (senator) than with a liberal Democrat who has been voting against the president,'' Duke says. ``Johnston has resorted to cowardly, personal attacks because he doesn't have the guts to stand up and debate me face to face,'' he said last week. Johnston says Duke celebrates Adolf Hitler's birthday. The senator emphasizes that Duke has been involved in writing books advising blacks on how to defend themselves against ``whitey'' and how women can please their men sexually. ``If I had done one-one hundredth of what he'd done, they would have run me out of town on a rail,'' Johnston said. The message: once a Klansman, always a Klansman. ``This is serious business. This is no Boy Scout. This is Louisiana's reputation at stake,'' Johnston said. ``We've had some real success (in attracting industry), not rapidly, but clearly,'' Johnston said in an interview between campaign stops. ``Duke could stop it dead in its tracks ... if Louisiana becomes known as the state of David Duke and the Ku Klux Klan. ``This election is about the legitimacy of David Duke. No one gives him a chance of winning. The question is whether he will be identified as a spokesman for Louisiana. ... He is a clear and present danger, to coin a phrase.''

DOC.HEAD: Assault Victims May Live in Fear Forever
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-What's Aggravated Assault? and PM-Assault List
DOC.TEXT: People stare at the scars on his throat as he waits in grocery store check-out lines. Sometimes they ask if he has a cold. Sometimes they ask if he fought in Vietnam. He never served in Vietnam, but he tells people he did, because he knows from experience that they won't want the truth. The truth is, eight years ago a stranger jammed a knife into his gut, spilling the intestines out of his slight frame, then slit his throat as he lay calling for help. It's those details people don't want to hear - details that still rattle him, causing his hands to shake uncontrollably, calling attention to nails bitten down to nothing. The sandy-haired young father is just one of several million people victimized by aggravated assault in the past decade. The attack swept away his optimism and trust, his devil-may-care fearlessness. Taking its place is fear - fear so real that after telling his story, he asked that his real name and hometown be kept secret. ``We live with the realization that it doesn't happen to somebody else,'' said the boyish, 33-year-old we'll call Larry Roberts. ``We know that people will hurt you.'' Murders may steal the headlines, but the number of serious assaults dwarfs the number of killings. Assault victims survive, but often are changed forever. ``The trauma of having looked at the jaws of death is something that is very rough to deal with,'' said John Stein, deputy director of the National Organization for Victims Assistance. Some 559,270 people - roughly the population of Columbus, Ohio, - were injured in aggravated assaults last year alone, according to the National Crime Survey, which annually interviews members of some 49,000 households and extrapolates from that to the entire nation. The survey found that 1.1 million others were victims of an attempted aggravated assault with a weapon - a gunshot flew by them, for example. On the night of June 6, 1982, Roberts was on leave from the Navy and interested mainly in getting in a last day of scuba diving before his aircraft carrier departed in two days. He was pitching a tent in a park when two strangers struck up a conversation. They seemed friendly enough. Then without warning, one of them stabbed Roberts in the abdomen and ran off with his scuba gear, wedding ring and $4 in cash. ``When I thought he was gone, I started to holler for help,'' Roberts said, a catch in his now-raspy voice. ``He came back through the woods and he tilted my head back and slit my throat twice. And then he tied my feet together and my hands back to two trees.'' Roberts eventually worked free, dragged himself 250 feet to a dirt road, holding in his intestines and pressing his chin toward his chest to keep the blood from spurting out. Help finally arrived the next morning. He spent 10 months in the hospital, undergoing at least 10 operations. The fear took over when he emerged from the hospital April 18, 1983. ``I used to take a gun with me wherever I went,'' he said. ``I was scared to death.'' In the next two years, Roberts moved his family six times. ``Something would happen, something would trigger me and we'd be gone,'' he said. They stopped running five years ago in rural Maryland so their elder daughter could start school and enjoy a semblance of a normal life. Four years ago, Roberts and his wife had a second daughter. In the meantime, his attacker pleaded guilty to attempted murder and served six years of a 10-year sentence before being freed as a model prisoner. Roberts still fears him - even though he believes his fear is irrational. He also insisted that the assailant's name not be used, in part because he doesn't want to antagonize him. Even now, Roberts' home is guarded by a large, loud dog nicknamed Norad, after the nation's early warning system for nuclear attacks. At night, their home is awash in light. Two sheriff's deputies live across the street. Roberts and his wife never employ baby-sitters because they don't trust strangers. The attack destroyed Roberts' career plans. The Navy discharged him involuntarily because he could no longer perform his job. Desperate to catch up for time lost, Roberts pushed himself too far. He has had a drinking problem. He spent two months in a psychiatric hospital last year. Today, he takes things more slowly, teaching scuba diving only part time while attending college. And after years of shying away from the world, he now tells his story to police groups, hoping to sensitize officers to victims' needs. ``The victim is a piece of evidence,'' said Andrew Turner, a criminal justice instructor at Wor Wic Tech Community College and a former Maryland police officer who has arranged some of Roberts' talks. ``If the guy survived, you had a good case. He could come and testify against the perpetrator.'' Turner said. ``Police don't see a guy healed up'' but still needing emotional support. Roberts finds the speeches therapeutic, despite the toll they take, and he has established a network of people who will help him when he cracks from the strain. It is important to Roberts that he controls the impact of the attack and not the other way around, but he conceded, ``It has given my life a different direction.'' Now there's yet another fear: AIDS. Roberts had numerous blood transfusions in 1982, before blood was tested for the deadly disease, and he refuses to be tested now. ``If I'm going to die of it,'' he said with a grimace, ``I don't want to know about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Aggravated Assault Definition Varies From State to State
With PM-The Scars of Assault
DOC.TEXT: What is an aggravated assault? It depends on who is talking. What one police officer calls aggravated assault may be only a simple assault to another and an encounter not even worth reporting to a third. ``In each state, the definition of aggravated assault varies widely,'' said Richard R. Bennett, a professor of justice at American University. ``In some states, it's any threat with a weapon other than a fist,'' he said. ``Elsewhere, it's a fist. In some states, it has to be an injury visible on the outside, internal bleeding won't do.'' Even the Justice Department's two major measures of national crime don't quite agree. The FBI's Uniform Crime Reports defines it as an ``unlawful attack ... for the purpose of inflicting severe or aggravated bodily injury.'' The assault usually involves a weapon or ``means likely to produce death or great bodily harm.'' The FBI also throws in attempted assault. The National Crime Survey, meanwhile, defines it as: ``Attack with a weapon, irrespective of whether or not there was injury, and attack without a weapon resulting either in serious injury (for example, broken bones, loss of teeth, internal injuries, or loss of consciousness) or an undetermined injury requiring two or more days of hospitalization. Also includes attempted assault with a weapon.'' The FBI report includes only crimes reported to police. The National Crime Survey, which annually interviews people who live in about 49,000 homes and apartments, learns of many more crimes that police never hear about. And, in part because of they are put together differently, the two surveys disagree about whether more Americans have been assaulted in the last decade. The FBI report says the rate of aggravated assault and attempted aggravated assault zoomed up 28.4 percent during the decade to a new high of 383 for every 100,000 people. The National Crime Survey, however, says the rate dropped 8.6 percent to 850 per 100,000.

DOC.HEAD: More Students Entering Workforce Today - Under Warranty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: This year's seniors at Fort Zumwalt high schools will be armed with more than just diplomas when they graduate: They'll also each be backed by a three-year warranty. In a small but growing number of schools, educators are adding an extra stamp of approval to their products - ``satisfaction guaranteed.'' ``The diploma used to be the guarantee,'' said Fort Zumwalt superintendent Bernard DuBray. ``But now we need to go above and beyond.'' Warranties such as Fort Zumwalt's typically guarantee that a graduate has learned the basic skills necessary to perform an entry-level job. If not, the school promises to provide additional training free of charge. ``It's accountability,'' said Bernard Sidman, superintendent of the Plymouth-Carver Regional School District in Massachusetts, which first included a three-year warranty with graduates' diplomas last spring and so far has had no students sent back. ``You hear an awful lot about the quality of public education and about public institutions of education not meeting their responsibilities in preparing students for entry into public life,'' Sidman said. ``We felt that if we were going to be asking the community to support us, maybe we should put ourselves on the line.'' But let the buyer beware: The amount of training received by guaranteed graduates may vary. Some schools simply warranty all their graduates. In others, the warranty program is designed mainly for students who want jobs straight out of high school. At Prince George's County School District in Maryland, students who want to be under warranty take a semester class focusing on job skills. The class has been developed with input from area business and industry leaders. In Missouri's Blue Springs School District, the state's largest, the graduate guarantee is printed on the back of a laminated wallet-size diploma. ``We've got some tremendous young people coming out of our system,'' said superintendent Charles McGraw. ``The nation's educational system is getting a bad rap and we wanted to make a point that our graduates had the skills to be good employees.'' But it's not enough just to warranty students if there's no recognition of what entry-level jobs in today's business world require, said Fritz Edelstein, senior fellow at the National Alliance for Business in Washington, D.C. Entry-level jobs are much more complex today, and school studies should reflect that, Edelstein said. McGraw agreed. ``I think we went through a time when the curriculum was out of date,'' he said. ``The curriculum has been slow changing - it hasn't kept up with the progress of technology that the business world required. So this is an attempt to be up to date.'' For instance, McGraw said, mechanical drawing is out, computer-assisted drafting is in. At the junior high level, a new exploratory course called industrial technology is being offered to introduce students to robotics, broadcasting, electronics and computer science, he said. Educators say skill guarantees have helped create a line of communication between schools and businesses. ``It's a feedback system,'' said Gary Marx, associate executive director of the American Association of School Administrators in Arlington, Va. ``It's a way for the schools to say to an employer, `It's all right to come back and let us know if there's something missing here.' '' In the Harlem Consolidated School District outside Rockford, Ill., this year's seniors will be able to earn a ``certificate of employability.'' The idea came about through meetings between school administrators and corporate leaders from the community, assistant superintendent Wayne Musholt said. During discussions, company executives expressed concerns about the employability of some of the students graduating today, particularly those who were not college-bound. ``Their concern was that some of the students didn't always have the best work habits and attitudes and we decided there ought to be a way of certifying them,'' Musholt said. To gain the certificate, students will have to earn the required number of high school credits and be absent no more than six days a year. In addition, their work ``attitudes'' will be rated by their teachers. The program at Prince George's County schools has received high marks from business and industry leaders, said Bonnie Jenkins, director of public affairs. ``The response has been overwhelmingly positive so far,'' she said. Employers prefer the students who have completed the special semester course, which emphasizes such areas as work habits and attitudes, reasoning and problem solving, and oral communication skills. ``So it's giving them an edge,'' she said. Last year was the first for the project, and no students have been referred back for more training, Jenkins said. Guarantees rekindle employers' interest in high school graduates and encourage potential dropouts to stay in school, said Thomas Shannon, executive director of the National School Boards Association in Alexandria, Va. ``This is adding a new dimension to the diploma,'' he said. ``It's a gimmick - it's right out of Madison Avenue - but secondly, it also sends a powerful message to the school staff that your work is really on the line.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Missile Threat Raises Appeal of Star Wars Spinoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The prospect of Iraq firing ballistic missiles at U.S. forces in the Arabian desert is stirring congressional interest in an obscure Star Wars spinoff effort to build defenses against close-range missile attacks. The United States has only a rudimentary defense against Iraq's missile arsenal, which U.S. intelligence agencies say is rapidly growing more sophisticated and is capable of carrying chemical warheads to targets inside Saudi Arabia. Even some of Congress' harshest critics of the Strategic Defense Initiative, more commonly called Star Wars or SDI, say the Iraqi missile threat might call for spending more on what the Pentagon calls ``theater missile defense.'' ``Maybe there's some justification for increasing that particular aspect of SDI,'' Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., said last week at a Senate Armed Services Committee hearing on the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf region. Kennedy's comment doesn't suggest a surge of support for the overall SDI program, which is aimed mainly at building a space-based defense against Soviet intercontinental ballistic missiles - those capable of reaching American soil. Congress is expected to slash at least $1 billion from President Bush's request for $4.6 billion in SDI funding for the 1991 budget year starting Oct. 1. The Iraqi crisis, however, has revived interest in SDI technologies that could be applied against short-range missiles that are proliferating in the Middle East. Two days after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion, the Senate approved a measure forcing the Pentagon to slow down work on strategic anti-missile defenses, while putting more emphasis on theater defense. The measure called for spending $180 million on theater defense in 1991 - $48 million more than Bush requested and $55 million more than in this year's budget. ``People are much more focused now on the threat posed by short-range missiles,'' Sen. Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M., a cosponsor of the Senate measure, said in an interview Friday. ``What makes it more immediate is the aggression that Saddam Hussein visited on Kuwait.'' One of the most promising theater missile defense projects is called the Extended Range Intercept Technology, or ERINT. LTV Corp., which runs the project under an SDI contract, is developing a lightweight missile to ram incoming ballistic missiles at five times the speed of sound, causing them to vaporize. Money for ERINT was cut back from planned levels this year, causing a several-month delay in its development schedule. The missile's first flight tests are set for 1992, according to Jess Granone of the Strategic Defense Command in Hunstville, Ala. Also in development is the Arrow system for defense against theater missiles. This highly secretive program is a joint effort between the Strategic Defense Command and Israeli Aircraft Industries. It is being developed to handle longer-range missiles than those that could be hit by the ERINT system. Currently the only U.S. defense against short-range missiles is the Army's Patriot air defense system, which was designed to shoot down aircraft, not missiles. The Patriot is being modified to knock down missiles, but the technology is rudimentary and the system has never been battle tested. Batteries of Patriot missiles are deployed with Army units in Saudi Arabia. Only about 3 percent of the total SDI budget of $3.6 billion this year was spent on developing missile systems to intercept and destroy short-range ballistic missiles. The main focus of SDI is to build a combination of ground- and space-based weapons and satellites to detect, track and destroy long-range missiles. The United States has spent $20 billion on this effort since 1983. At the Senate Armed Services hearing, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney jumped at the opportunity to emphasize U.S. vulnerability to non-Soviet missiles - an argument that carried little weight before Bush dispatched tens of thousands of GIs to Saudi Arabia after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. ``We see now, as we contemplate the possibility of hostilities with Iraq, that we're faced with a country that has ballistic missiles, short-range systems,'' Cheney said. ``SDI is that portion of our budget where we currently have ensconced the programs that would allow us to deal with a short-range tactical ballistic missile threat.''

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Trying to Rescue Toddler Trapped at Bottom of Hole
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with firemen breaking through hard clay; prepared to snatch toddler if cave-in occurs. Pickup 4th graf pvs., `The boys.' DELETES last 2 grafs of outdated information.
DOC.TEXT: A toddler fell to the bottom of a 12-foot narrow construction hole Saturday afternoon and firefighters, hampered by the danger of a cave-in, worked into the night trying to rescue him. Firemen broke through a layer of hard clay shortly after 9 p.m. in their efforts to dig a parallel shaft to rescue 20-month-old Kevin Davis from the hole at his family's home in southeast Denver. The shaft Kevin fell into is about 18-inches wide at the top and was to be filled with reinforced concrete for a remodeling project. Denver policeman W.C. Hoffman said the threat of a cave-in diminished after diggers finally broke through the clay that had slowed digging efforts throughout the night. ``We're letting him sleep for now. He's been sleeping off and on. We've had to play around with the oxygen (tube to the boy) because he doesn't like the sound (hissing) of the oxygen. Every time he wakes up he cries,'' Hoffman said. Rescuers were ready should there be a cave-in on the little boy, who is too young to grab a rope that could be lowered to him. ``We've got a pole with a snare in the hole. If it caves in, we'll grab him with that and pull him up,'' said Hoffman. However, he said the snare would break any limb they might pull on. The boys' parents, Tom and Lisa Davis, were talking to Kevin, trying to soothe him during the rescue effort. Oxygen was being pumped into the shaft. Kevin fell into the shaft about 4 p.m.

Iraq Opens Border to Hundreds of Refugees From Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: At least 1,000 refugees from Kuwait streamed into Saudi Arabia on Saturday after Iraqi border guards opened at least one frontier crossing. Scores of newly arrived Kuwaitis were lined up early Sunday to be processed at a Saudi government office in this border town and waiting to use pay phones to call relatives who had fled Kuwait earlier. A Saudi government source who had spoken to an official at the border said he was told that about 1,000 Kuwaitis had crossed into Khafji on the Saudi side and each was being registered by the Saudi government. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said most government officials had been instructed to say publicly that there had been no abnormal activity at the crossing point. Iraq's motives for opening the border were not immediately clear. Several of the Kuwaiti refugees said the border had been abruptly opened Friday, but most of those who left did so on Saturday. A Kuwait City lawyer, who gave his name only as Shaheen, said he didn't know why the frontier had been opened, but said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``is asking the Kuwaitis to leave Kuwait and go out across the border.'' He said that in the last three days about 25 young Kuwaitis, ranging in age from 15 to 25, had been taken away by Iraqi soldiers for unknown reasons. Shaheen added that he had heard rumors of several Americans and other Westerners hiding in Kuwait. ``If you help a Westerner in your home you will be hanged, but some people are still hiding them,'' he said, referring to Iraqi threats that persons caught sheltering Westerners would be put to death. A group of 11 Kuwaiti families, 88 people in all, arrived in Dhahran, 200 miles south of the border, Saturday night and told of traveling in a convoy of cars from Kuwait City. They said they made the trip because Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had stated two days ago that all vehicles with Kuwaiti registry would be permitted to cross into Saudi Arabia. Speaking through an interpreter at a local hotel, several members of the group said they were stopped by Iraqi troops six times and were robbed of belongings including passports, drivers licenses, cassettes and even wedding invitations. A hotel clerk at Khafji, on the Saudi side of the border, said refugees of ``all nationalities, including Westerners, Indians and others,'' began streaming across about 10 a.m., and at midnight ``they are still coming, little by little.'' The clerk at the Hotel Saad Al-Orasi, who identified himself as Hosaria Kumara, said the refugees were coming by car and most apparently were heading south toward Dhahran. One of the refugees in Khafji, Affa Abdullah, said she had left her home with 15 family members after learning from a friend that the border was open. She said the Iraqis took their passports and drivers licenses at a checkpoint before they reached the border. Most of the Kuwaitis at the processing center did not appear to have passports. ``When we got to the border, the Iraqis told us to go, but I don't know why,'' she said. She said food supplies were running low and stores were limiting customers to single purchases of various items. The shortages were even affecting the Iraqi occupation troops. She said that during the past month Iraqi soldiers would come to her home and take food and water. ``One soldier asked me whether I liked Saddam (Hussein) or Jaber. If i told him I liked Kuwait and Jaber, I would be killed.'' The emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber el-Ahmed al-Sabah, heads the Kuwaiti government-in-exile based in the southwestern Saudi city of Taif. Another Kuwaiti, who gave his name only as Adel, said the border was open Friday and Saturday, but ``today maybe it will be closed.'' Adel said Kuwaitis had heard Saddam's call for an Islamic holy war against the United States, but he said the Iraqis ``don't have even a little Islam in their hearts or in their minds.'' ``Israel is better than Saddam,'' he said. ``The Israelis take from the Palestinians but without killing them or stealing their food and water. Saddam is killing Kuwait.'' Another man, who identified himself only by his first name Manfour, said the Iraqi soldiers were ``stealing everything,'' including the loudspeakers from mosques used to call the faithful to their daily prayers. Refugees, mostly Kuwaitis, have been trickling into Saudi Arabia since Aug. 2, when Iraq invaded Kuwait. The flow has depended largely on Iraqi security, which has been tight at times and loose at others.

DOC.TEXT: In their first nomination for an Emmy award, television's irrevent ``The Simpsons'' won the trophy for Outstanding Animated Program Saturday night. Two versions of ``The Simpsons'' were nominated: a Christmas special and the regular series, with the latter taking the award. DOC.HEAD: UAW, General Motors Keep Talking After Contract Deadline Passes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, `Both sides...', to UPDATE with talks continuing, no announcement to be made.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WDR1
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers and General Motors Corp. froze the clock and continued negotiations Saturday toward a new three-year agreement coverng 300,000 GM workers nationwide. Meanwhile, 12,800 Canadian Auto Workers union members struck Ford of Canada early Saturday after talks there broke off. No plants involved operate on weekends so any strike impact won't be felt until Monday. ``We still have a very significant distance between the two positions,'' Ford's chief negotiator, Don MacKenzie, said after talks broke off. The strike is the first against Ford of Canada since 1976. Both sides have refused to disclose details of their proposals and demands. Talks resumed Saturday in Detroit and continued past midnight into Sunday morning. Bargaining also resumed Saturday in Toronto. Spokesmen for both sides said talks would continue through the night, and no announcement would be made before 9 a.m. Sunday. The 1987 GM-UAW contract covering workers in 29 states expired at midnight Friday. Because all but one of GM's plants are idle on weekends, a strike would be only symbolic until Monday. No new deadline for an agreement has been set in the GM talks, but the union called a meeting Monday for its 300-member GM national bargaining council. That session could be used to review details of the agreement or brief local leaders on the talks. It also could be used to gauge leaders' feelings on a strike authorization made a week ago. A GM strike Monday, even at just one critical parts plant, could quickly disrupt vehicle production by the world's largest automaker. That's because it uses a system that delivers parts to its assembly plants just before they are needed for installation in a vehicle. Both sides have refused to disclose the progress of the negotiations, but aspects of job security and benefits for GM workers remained unresolved Saturday. Talks initially stalled over GM's insistence that a no-layoff pledge be limited to workers with 20 or more years of seniority. The UAW wanted all workers covered. GM countered with an offer to protect workers with 15 years of seniority in exchange for more flexibility to move workers within and between plants and an increase in the average number of minutes worked per hour from 46 to 55, the Detroit Free Press reported Saturday. Other bargaining issues include a UAW proposal to limit to three weeks a year the amount of time a worker can be laid off because of falling sales; and a GM proposal to eliminate a plan to hire one new worker for every two who quit, die or retire. Eliminating the plan could allow GM to trim its work force by 100,000. Less than two hours before Friday's deadline, top union leaders told local leaders both sides had agreed to keep talking and extend the existing contract's provisions. Negotiations began in July. ``I think we'll have a settlement by the end of the weekend,'' President Jerry Schmidt of UAW Local 1005 in Parma, Ohio, said after learning of the extension. ``I think most of the members are happy with the decision'' to extend the talks. The UAW in 1970 hit GM with a 69-day strike, the longest against the automaker except for the 1936-37 sit-down strikes in Flint that gave birth to the union. The negotiations could ultimately affect employees of GM, Ford and Chrysler Corp., whose UAW national contracts expired at midnight Friday. The union froze negotiations at Ford and Chrysler pending the outcome of the GM talks. The UAW plans to use an agreement ratified by GM workers as a pattern for contracts with Ford and Chrysler.

DOC.HEAD: France Promises More Men, Machines; U.N. Condemns Iraqi Raids
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Security Council condemning Iraq for raids on foreign compounds in Kuwait. Pickup 4th pvs, `The Washington...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY5,6,9, AMM1,7 LON1,DHA1
DOC.TEXT: France retaliated Saturday for Iraq's raid on its official residence in Kuwait, expelling dozens of Iraqi diplomats and civilians and pledging to send warplanes, tanks, helicopters and 4,000 troops to Saudi Arabia. Refugees from Kuwait crossed into Saudi Arabia by the hundreds after Iraqi border guards opened the frontier. The U.N. Security Council early Sunday unanimously condemned Iraq's raids against French and other embassy compounds in Kuwait and warned further sanctions against Baghdad were likely. U.S. diplomats said an aerial blockade and secondary sanctions against nations flouting the U.N. trade embargo would be considered urgently, beginning Sunday. The Washington Post reported in its Sunday editions that the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff have concluded that American air power - including a massive bombing campaign against Baghdad that specifically targets Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and his family - is the only effective option to force Iraqi forces from Kuwait if war breaks out. Air Force chief of staff Michael J. Dugan said ``air power is the only answer that's available to our country'' to avoid a bloody ground war, the newspaper said. The French moves came in response to raids by Iraqi troops on the missions or diplomatic residences of France, Canada and Belgium Friday. Four French citizens, including the military attache, and the consuls of five nations including the United States were detained in the raids. The French attache and the consuls were released but France said the three other French nationals still were being held Saturday. Iraq at first denied the raids on the diplomatic compounds occurred and threatened reciprocal measures. Later, while not admitting to the raids, Saddam sought to cool French anger by announcing he would allow elderly and ailing Frenchmen to leave Iraq and Kuwait on Monday. Saddam's offer followed a plea from former Algerian President Ahmed Ben Bella, who met Saddam in Baghdad on Saturday, the Iraqi News Agency reported. It quoted Saddam as saying he hoped his decision ``would provide the fair-minded among the French people with the opportunity to reconsider their actions away from American and Zionist pressures.'' French President Francois Mitterrand urged widening the U.N. economic sanctions on Iraq to include air traffic and punishment of parties who broke sanctions, although the French request for the Security Council meeting didn't mention either proposal. ``We will do what must be done,'' Mitterrand told reporters after an emergency Cabinet meeting. ``But we won't be taking hostages.'' Iraq's ambassador to France, Abdelrazzek al-Hachimi, said Iraq ``will take reciprocal measures at a diplomatic level'' in response to the expulsion of Iraqi diplomats. He did not elaborate. A spokesman quoted by the Iraqi news agency denied the raid took place and said a French counselor had been escorted back to the French compound after he ``was found in the private home of a female member of Kuwait's former ruling family.'' The spokesman said France ``shoulders full responsibility for any reaction this intentional escalation of the situation will lead to.'' France's actions represented the strongest move yet by France against Iraq, a country it long considered a friend and supplied weapons. The Foreign Ministry summoned al-Hachimi Satuday to hear the expulsion order against 11 embassy personnel, ministry spokesman Daniel Bernard said. France also will expel 26 Iraqi civilian and military personnel taking training courses in France, and 10 other Iraqis whom Mitterrand labeled ``secret agents,'' AFP reported, citing unidentified sources. Remaining Iraqi diplomats will be confined to the Paris city limits, Mitterrand said. Iraq on Aug. 24 ordered the 60 embassies in Kuwait to shut and move their representation to Baghdad. Power and water was cut to missions that remained open and many were surrounded by Iraqi troops. But 17 missions remained open to show they still recognized Kuwait as a sovereign nation and to keep in touch with the foreigners who remain trapped in the emirate. About 1,550 Americans are captive in Kuwait and Iraq, and many men are being held at strategic Iraqi installations to deter any attack by U.S.-led forces. President Saddam Hussein has allowed many Western women and children to leave. A Saudi government source who had spoken to an official at the Saudi-Kuwaiti border said he was told that about 1,000 people crossed over Saturday. There were no details on Iraq's motives for opening the border. Members of one Kuwaiti family that crossed the border and then traveled 200 miles south to Dhahran said they made the trip because Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had stated two days ago that all vehicles with Kuwaiti registry would be permitted to cross into Saudi Arabia. On Saturday, an Iraqi Airways jetliner left London's Gatwick airport for Baltimore carrying more than 350 evacuees, mostly American women and children. Another U.S.-chartered Iraqi Airways jetliner carrying 165 evacuees flew from Baghdad to London, the U.S. Embassy in London said. The passengers included 73 Americans, but most of the others on board had American relatives or were dual passport holders and were headed for the United States, according to a Gatwick airport official. They were spending the night at a hotel, and were to depart Sunday afternoon on a chartered flight to Baltimore, a U.S. Embassy official said. Recent escapees from Kuwait have said that the emirate, once a showcase of stability and wealth, has been ravaged beyond recognition by Saddam's marauding soldiers and by civilian Iraqi looters. They said, however, tha the most critical problem facing Kuwaitis was finding enough food to eat. The U.N. embargo has stopped shipments of food and other supplies into Kuwait and Iraq. The Times of London quoted Victor Watkins, an official of the World Society for the Protection of Animals, as saying Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait have eaten 70 percent of the edible animals in Kuwait's zoo. The newspaper did not specify how Watkins got his information or how many animals were in the zoo. Secretary of State James A. Baker III met Saturday with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl in his latest effort to gain financial and military support for the U.S.-led multinational force in the gulf. After the meeting, Kohl announced West Germany had promised $2 billion to the military effort. West Germany, along with Japan, had been criticized for not doing enough in the campaign against Iraq. Japan has promised $4 billion in aid. The West German constitution prohibits Bonn from sending forces outside the NATO area, and the Japanese charter prohibits deployment outside Japanese territory. Both nations, however, are heavily dependent on imported oil. The deployment of 150,000 U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia and about 30 warships in the gulf area is costing the United States $1 billion monthly. The soldiers face about 265,000 Iraqi troops along Kuwait's border with Saudi Arabia. On Friday, Canada, Belgium, Italy and Britain promised to bolster their forces in the gulf with tanks, combat troops, fighter planes and more ships. The military effort, along with the U.N. economic sanctions, aims at pressuring Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, which it invaded Aug. 2 and annexed in a dispute over oil, land and money.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Condemns Iraqi Raids, Further Measures Likely
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with resolution unanimously approved, comment. Pickup 10th pvs, `The Iraqi...'
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council early Sunday unanimously condemned Iraq's raids on French and other embassy compounds in Kuwait and warned that further sanctions against Baghdad were likely. U.S. diplomats said an aerial blockade and secondary sanctions against nations flouting the U.N. trade embargo would be considered urgently, beginning Sunday. The vote was 15-0 in the emergency session sought by France. ``By singling out diplomatic missions for attack, Iraq confirms its preference for instruments of force to instruments of diplomacy and negotiation,'' said U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering. ``As early as possible ... we must take concrete steps under Chapter 7 of the U.N. Charter to deal with Iraq's continued violations of council resolutions, the U.N. Charter and international law. The resolution was the seventh adopted overwhelmingly by the council since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The council has condemned the occupation, demanded release of all foreign hostages, imposed a trade embargo and approved the use of maritime force to implement the embargo. Numerous speakers said that Iraq had violated international law on protection of diplomatic missions by cutting off water, power, food and other resources to foreign missions in Kuwait City. Numerous speakers said that Iraq had violated international law on protection of diplomatic missions by cutting off water, power, food and other resources to foreign missions in Kuwait City. The council expressed outrage at Iraq's violation Friday of the French, Belgian and Canadian embassy compounds, the detention of diplomats and kidnapping of three French nationals. The vote came about 3 a.m. EDT Sunday after hours of informal consultations by members of the 15-nation council. The resolution ``strongly condemns aggressive acts perpetrated by Iraq against diplomatic premises and personnel in Kuwait as well as the abduction of foreign nationals who were present in those premises.'' The resolution expresses outrage and demands the immediate release of all foreign nationals. In a warning of further action, the resolution says it would ``pursue its consultations urgently in order to take further concrete measures as soon as possible.'' President Francois Mitterrand said Saturday that his government would ask that the U.N. trade embargo be widened to include air traffic to Iraq and punishment of countries violating the blockade. The Iraqi government denied it raided any diplomatic homes or buildings in Kuwait. Iraq has annexed Kuwait and withdrawn the diplomatic privileges and immunity of embassies there, ordering them to move to Baghdad. An Iraqi spokesman said there were strict instructions against entering foreign missions, although they had not been regarded as diplomatic territory since Aug. 24, according to the Iraqi News Agency. The Iraqi government now calls Kuwait a province of Iraq and says the 1961 Vienna Conventions on Diplomatic and Consular relations do not apply. The council already has said that force may be used to implement the sweeping U.N. trade embargo against Iraq in terms of maritime shipping. But an air embargo, although included in the general U.N. sanctions, is difficult to implement because forcing planes down involves military risk and could mean attack, diplomats said. An air embargo also would require cooperation of all of Iraq's neighbors. In addition, the diplomats said, drafting the language for such a blockade would be time-consuming and was unlikely to be supported by the Soviet Union, China and some Third World nations. Iraq has rejected all six previous Security Council resolutions condemning Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion and occupation of Kuwait. The members of the Security Council are Britain, Canada, China, Colombia, Cuba, Ethiopia, Finland, France, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania, the Soviet Union, the United States, Yemen and Zaire.

DOC.TEXT: President Francois Mitterrand reacted sharply Saturday to an Iraqi raid on the French diplomatic compound in Kuwait by expelling dozens of Iraqis and dispatching 4,000 troops to Saudi Arabia. ``We will do what must be done,'' Mitterrand told a news conference following an emergency Cabinet meeting on Saturday morning. Mitterrand also urged the U.N. Security Council to extend the embargo against Iraq to air shipments and set penalties for companies or countries violating the sanctions. The council voted 15-0 early Sunday to condemn the Iraqi actions, and it warned that further sanctions against Baghdad were likely. In addition to the soldiers, Mitterrand said France will deploy warplanes, tanks and helicopters in Saudi Arabia to bolster the U.S.-led multinational force created after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The Cabinet meeting came one day after Iraqi troops raided the diplomatic compounds of France, Canada and Belgium in occupied Kuwait City. The troops briefly detained five Western consuls - including an American - and captured four French citizens. Only one of the four, France's military attache, was freed later. The official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus, denied that Iraqi soldiers had raided the diplomatic compounds. The news agency said the French government ``shoulders full responsibility for any reaction this intentional escalation of the situation will lead to.'' But it reported later that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein would allow elderly and ailing Frenchmen banned from leaving Kuwait and Iraq to depart on Monday. Saddam's decision came in response to a plea from former Algerian President Ahmed Ben Bella, who met the Iraqi leader Saturday in Baghdad, INA said. French officials said they had no official confirmation of the report. The Foreign Ministry summoned Iraqi Ambassador Abdelrazzak al-Hachimi late Saturday to receive the expulsion order for 11 of his aides, ministry spokesman Daniel Bernard said. Earlier in the day, al-Hachimi said Iraq ``will take reciprocal measures at the diplomatic level.'' The French news agency Agence France-Presse said the Iraqi Embassy personnel to be expelled included six diplomats, three military attaches and two other officers from the Iraqi military mission. Another 10 Iraqis labeled by Mitterrand as secret agents were to be expelled as quickly as possible, said AFP citing authorized sources. Mitterrand said 26 other Iraqi military and civilian personnel receiving training in France at the time of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait would also be expelled. He said the remaining Iraqi diplomats will be confined to Paris. ``We won't be taking hostages,'' Mitterrand said. ``The some 1,400 Iraqi civilians (in France) will not be made the object of these particular measures so long as they conform to our laws.'' About 400 French nationals remain in Iraq and Kuwait, and some are being held as human shields at strategic installations to deter any attack. Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement held talks with his Saudi counterpart, Prince Sultan, in Jiddah on Saturday to make arrangements for the French deployment. France already has sent 180 paratroopers to the United Arab Emirates and has nine warships in the region or en route, including the aircraft carrier Clemenceau. The Clemenceau is carrying a unit of 800 men and 48 helicopters. France will also be sending 30 warplanes, units from a light armored division with 48 tanks and part of an artillery regiment with ground-to-air missiles. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, and annexed the oil-rich emirate several days later. Saddam ordered all diplomatic missions in Kuwait to close down by Aug. 24 and move operations to Baghdad. Iraqi troops have since ringed most of the embassies that defied the deadline.
