DOC.TEXT: A 20-month-old boy was removed safely from a narrow, 12-foot-deep foundation hole in a remodeling project at his parents' home Sunday morning, ending a 14-hour ordeal. Oxygen was pumped into the narrow shaft during the overnight operation to rescue Kevin Davis, while teams from four metropolitan fire departments dug a parallel rescue shaft and then tunneled some five feet to the trapped child. Kevin, son of Tom and Lisa Davis, was asleep when Denver fireman Joe Cipri finally broke through and saw his face. ``When I went and grabbed his hand, he actually helped himself out of the hole,'' the smiling Cipri said shortly after the 6 a.m. rescue. The youngster was admitted to Denver General Hospital in fair condition, Dr. Jack Row said. ``He was alert and responded very well and normally to his parents,'' Row said. Firefighter Kevin Duncan was in the rescue tunnel with Cipri and did the final, delicate cutting away of the dirt to avoid a cave-in. He said Kevin ``was in pretty good shape. He fell asleep. He was pretty much out of it, still in a daze.'' Firemen strapped Kevin into a splint-like device that cradled the child's head, neck and upper body as they extricated him from the narrow shaft. The rescuers hooted and yelled with joy as the boy emerged. The little blonde boy with a dirt-smudged face was blinking and calm when placed on a gurney and wheeled to a waiting ambulance. A police motorcycle escort then led the ambulance to the hospital. The toddler fell into the 18-inch wide hole about 4 p.m. Saturday at an addition being built at his parents' home. Policeman W.C. Hoffman said shortly before 1 a.m. that heavy equipment called a ``Vac-Hoe,'' which works off compressed air and vacuums out the loose dirt, had finished the rescue vertical shaft some 5 feet from the exhausted toddler and was drilling across to the child. The excavating machine worked until about eight inches from the boy. The final breakthrough was done slowly by hand trowels. The incident was reminiscent of the October 1987 ordeal of Jessica McClure, the toddler who spent 58 hours in a well in Midland, Texas. The arduous effort to free her gripped the nation and her final emergence safe in the arms of rescue workers was televised nationally.

DOC.HEAD: Hearings Remove Some of the Mystery Surrounding Souter
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: David H. Souter, described by one senator early in his Supreme Court confirmation hearings as ``the stealth nominee,'' is not the same mystery man he may have been to many Americans just days ago. His two days of nationally televised testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee yielded significant insights into Souter the man and Souter the judge. Everyone was not satisfied with his answers, especially his reluctance to detail his views on abortion. But at least something was learned of this New Hampshire judge who was virtually unknown outside his home state when he was tapped by President Bush in July. Perhaps more will be learned Monday - Souter's 51st birthday - when he returns for a third day of answering senators' questions. Here's some of what has been learned so far: -Souter says he gave the Bush administration no assurances about how he would vote on any case, including one involving abortion rights. And he says he has not made up his mind about how he might vote if the court were asked to overturn its 1973 decision in Roe vs. Wade legalizing abortion. -He believes the Constitution provides a general right of privacy even though such a right is not specifically mentioned, and that the right extends to married women's use of contraceptives. -He thinks constitutional provisions should not be interpreted to mean only what their framers intended, but what they mean in today's world. That separates him from those conservatives who espouse an ``original intent'' approach. -He disagrees with Justice Antonin Scalia, the high court's most conservative member, about how judges should search out American tradition in determining some forms of constitutional protection. In a recent decision, Scalia said the father of a child born out of wedlock is not entitled to certain parental rights because those rights previously had been recognized only for married people. Souter said he found that reasoning too confining. -He never heard his parents refer to another human being in racial or ethnic terms. ``I am glad I am conditioned by my beginnings, and I am glad I do not have to overcome them,'' Souter told the committee. -He is not unflappable. Questioned by Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., near the end of Friday's session, Souter for the first time began answering before his interrogator had finished speaking. And he gave an answer that could have been interpreted as callous. When asked about a quote attributed to him that letting illiterate people vote ``dilutes the votes of those people who can read,'' he answered Kennedy by stating, ``That's kind of a statement of math.'' -He doesn't think the Supreme Court should stick its nose into matters where it has no constitutional responsibility to act, but believes the court sometimes ``is left to act alone when the political branches do not act beforehand.'' -He applauds one such example, the court's 1954 decision outlawing the racial segregation of America's public schools. -He does not object when called a conservative judge, and thinks judges have to guard against using their positions of power to impose purely personal viewpoints. -He is aware that, in these televised hearings, he is speaking to the American public as well as to 14 committee members. Souter at one point told Joseph Biden, the Delaware Democrat who chairs the committee, that an explanation was intended for those not as familiar with the subject at hand. Souter is a well-prepared, attentive and respectful witness who on occasion shows flashes of a dry wit. His often-lengthy oral answers, delivered in a Yankee accent that makes Miranda ``Mirander'' and law ``lawr,'' are well organized and impeccably grammatical. A lifelong bachelor, he has tried hard to tell the committee of the various life experiences that have shaped his view of the world. The message he and his White House helpers want sent: I am not a hermit or an isolated scholar. It appears the judiciary committee has conceded the point, and may be on the verge of conceding Souter's confirmation. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Richard Carelli has covered the Supreme Court for The Associated Press since 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Official Investigates Lottery - And Wins It
DOC.TEXT: The official appointed by President Corazon Aquino to investigate alleged rigging of the government lottery won the top prize Sunday in a drawing televised to restore public confidence. Retired Brig. Gen. Alfredo Lim, director of the National Bureau of Investigation, held the winning ticket in the weekly lottery worth $200,000, officials of the Philippine Charity Sweepstakes Office said. Officials said Lim bought a book of 80 tickets while investigating allegations that the Sept. 1 drawing was rigged. A judge and a lawyer who were involved in the Sept. 1 drawing have been arrested and the board of directors of the weekly sweepstakes resigned following the scandal. Mrs. Aquino, however, refused to accept the resignations of the board members, who include Environment Secretary Fulgencio Factoran, Solicitor General Francisco Chavez and the wife of Health Secretary Alfredo Bengzon. Unlike previous drawings, Sunday's drawing was telecast live as part of the government's effort to convince the public that the lottery is fair and honest.

DOC.HEAD: Police Fire on Transport Workers, 15 Injured
DOC.TEXT: Police in western Bangladesh opened fire on transport workers striking against alleged police harassment and 15 people were injured, according to news reports Sunday. The indefinite strike halted bus traffic in 16 districts and stranded thousands of bus passengers, the government-owned Dainik Bangla newspaper reported. Police and demonstrators clashed in Pabna, 75 miles northwest of Dhaka, the paper said, but it did not specify how many of the injured were protesters and how many were police. It also did not say how many were wounded by the gunfire. Police said they opened fire when the workers tried to storm an office of the road transport authority. On Saturday, 50 people were injured when pro-government workers and opposition-backed laborers clashed, using homemade bombs and knives, over the ouster of a union leader in Adamjee, 10 miles south of Dhaka, police said.

DOC.HEAD: MiG-23 Crashes at Air Show, Kills Hungarian Air Force Pilot
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet-built MiG-23 crashed Sunday during an air show at an airport west of Budapest, killing its Hungarian air force pilot, the Hungarian news agency MTI reported. The agency said Maj. Karoly Soproni died when his jet fighter slammed into the ground at Papa airport, 75 miles west of the capital. There were no other injuries reported. The Defense Ministry has begun an investigation, MTI said, and has asked members of the public who took snapshots and video footage of the accident to submit it to airport authorities.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush Message Airs on Iraqi TV; U.N. Condemns Embassy Raids
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Bush speech on Iraqi television, Iraqi response, report that Bangladesh embassy officials' homes raided. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `The Security Council's...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DHA4, AMM3
DOC.TEXT: International indignation mounted Sunday over Iraq's raids on embassies in occupied Kuwait, with the U.N. Security Council condemning the incursions and the Soviet Union and Italy sharply protesting the Iraqi action. Iraqi television, meanwhile, aired a videotaped message from President Bush to the Iraqi people on Sunday, but followed it up with a stinging response from Baghdad. ``Saddam Hussein tells you that this crisis is a struggle between Iraq and America. In fact, it is Iraq against the world,'' said Bush, standing in front of his desk with the American flag behind him. The lengthy Iraqi response blamed ``imperialist countries'' for inflaming tensions in the Persian Gulf region. ``He wants to be the leader of the world,'' Iraqi announcer said of Bush. Italy, acting in response to last week's Iraqi raids on diplomatic premises of France, Canada, Belgium and the Netherlands, expelled several Iraqi Embassy employees and limited the movement of others. The Italian Foreign Ministry, in a communique, said all military officials in the military attache's office at the Iraqi Embassy in Rome were given 10 days to leave the country. Moscow, too, spoke out Sunday against the storming of diplomatic premises in Kuwait. ``The Soviet Union condemns this action by Iraqi occupying authorities, since it is inadmissible from the viewpoint of international law,'' said the Soviet Foreign Ministry, as quoted by the official news agency Tass. Prior to the invasion of Kuwait, the Soviet Union was a chief ally of Iraq. Two Tunisian newspapers reported Sunday that Iraqi troops had entered the Tunisian Embassy in Kuwait as well. The newspapers Assabah and Le Temps did not cite sources for their reports nor say when the incident took place. In Bangladesh, the Bengali-language newspaper Ittefaq said soldiers stormed the residences of two embassy officials on Friday. Acting Foreign Secretary Musafizur Rahman said if the report were true, Bangladesh would ``strongly condemn'' the action. The Security Council's condemnation of Iraq's embassy raids was unanimous, and the council warned further sanctions against Baghdad were likely. U.S. diplomats said an aerial blockade and secondary sanctions against nations flouting the U.N. trade embargo would be considered urgently, beginning Sunday. In another development, Belgium's foreign minister said Sunday that European Community countries would consider taking new punitive measures against Iraqi diplomats in response to the embassy raids in Kuwait. The state-owned Middle East News Agency quoted the Belgian official, Mark Eyskens, as saying the 12-member European Comminuty is due to meet Monday in Brussels to discuss the measures. Eyskens spoke after meeting President Hosni Mubarak. Sunday also brought indications that the fate of foreigners in Iraq is becoming more precarious. Iraqi soldiers have seized 12 West Germans in Kuwait and have taken them to an unknown location, bringing to 43 the number of West Germans held hostage by Iraq, the West German Foreign Ministry said Sunday. Also, a Sri Lankan Cabinet minister was quoted Sunday as saying Iraq has threatened to cut off food and water to Sri Lankans in Kuwait unless they are evacuated within five weeks. ``The lives of Sri Lankans would be in terrible danger if steps are not taken to evacuate them within the ultimatium set by Iraq,'' Labor Minister Gamalth Premachandra, who returned last week from a trip to Kuwait, Iraq and Jordan, told the Sunday Island newspaper. Iraq opened its border with Saudi Arabia for the first time in a month to Kuwaitis, and there was a huge exodus on Saturday and Sunday. Most left posessions behind, but brought with them tales of terror and anarchy. At least 1,500 refugees were expected to cross on Sunday, border officials said. At least 1,000 entered Saudi Arabia on Saturday. Another U.S.-chartered Iraqi Airways jetliner carrying 165 evacuees flew Saturday from Baghdad to London, the U.S. Embassy in London said, and was traveling on to the Washington area on Sunday afternoon. The passengers included 73 Americans, but most of the others on board had American relatives or were dual passport holders and were headed for the United States, according to a Gatwick airport official. Meanwhile, a senior Iranian delegation arrived in Iraq Sunday for talks on patching up relations between the two nations. The visit follows up on recent talks in Tehran between Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz and his Iranian counterpart, Ali Akbar Velayati. Aziz was believed to be seeking Iran's cooperation in beating the United Nations-imposed trade and economic embargo on Iraq and Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Burned to Death; Estranged Husband Charged
DOC.TEXT: A man was charged with capital murder after he allegedly doused his estranged wife with flammable liquid and set her ablaze while her 7-year-old daughter watched, police said. Cyrus W. Moore, 34, was being held without bond Sunday in the death of 31-year-old Bobbie Jean Stafford, officials said. Fire Department arson investigator Ken Ferro said Moore went to Ms. Stafford's home Saturday and argued with her. They began to struggle and Moore poured some type of flammable liquid on Ms. Stafford and then set her on fire, Ferro said. Ms. Stafford was able to scream to her daughter to call 911. When authorities arrived, Ms. Stafford was dead and flames had spread through a bedroom and into the attic. Ms. Stafford's daughter and 2-year-old son, who was sleeping, were not injured. Moore was treated at Ben Taub Hospital for burns on his forearms before being taken into custody by arson investigators.

DOC.HEAD: China Steps Up Security in Tibet
DOC.TEXT: Chinese authorities have renewed a call for tighter security measures in the Tibetan capital of Lhasa and organized more classes on patriotism for Tibet's rebellious monks, an official report said. ``People are concerned about the situation in Lhasa, therefore to ensure stability in Lhasa is ... of prime importance,'' the Sept. 5 Tibet Daily quoted Tibet's deputy Communist Party secretary, Gyaincain Norbu, as saying. The report was seen in Beijing on Sunday. Norbu, who spoke at a meeting of regional party and government officials, said Lhasa was the target of destructive plots by separatists. He urged tighter administrative control to ensure public security in the capital, and more classes on patriotism and national unity for Tibet's Buddhist monks. He warned that those who ``refused to comply with the laws and adhere to their separatist ideas would be penalized, without exception.'' It was unclear whether his comments were linked to any recent disturbance in Lhasa. The party official said ``overall social order is essential for a stable Lhasa and Asian Games,'' which start Saturday. Scores of people have been killed in pro-independence riots in Tibet in the past two years. The latest reported unrest was in June, when 13 monks tried to demonstrate and about 100 university students held a separate pro-independence rally, according to Tibetan exiles in neighboring India. Police arrested the monks and broke up the rally. Tens of thousands of Chinese soldiers are stationed in Tibet. Beijing claims that the strategic mountainous region has been part of China since the 13th century, but many Tibetans say they enjoyed de facto independence for many years.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Broadcasts Bush Video, With Stinging Response
With BC-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi television on Sunday broadcast a taped message from President Bush to the Iraqi people, but followed it up with a scathing response from Saddam Hussein. ``Iraq stands isolated and alone,'' Bush said in his message from the Oval Office. ``Saddam Hussein tells you that this crisis is a struggle between Iraq and America. In fact, it is Iraq against the world.'' Iraqi television appeared to have broadcast the message in its entirety Sunday evening around 7 p.m. local time (11 a.m. EDT). ``Iraq finds itself on the brink of war,'' Bush said, standing in front of his desk with an American flag behind him. But, he said, ``war is not inevitable. It is still possible to bring this crisis to a peaceful end.'' The Iraqi response, which was far longer than Bush's message, assailed the ``claims and lies'' of the U.S. president. ``The words show he is trying to impose himself on world public opinion,'' the announcer said in a statement translated by Cable News Network. It said Bush wanted to be ``the dictator of the whole world.'' ``Bush is envious of Iraq and of its people,'' said the Iraqi message. ``Iraq will always fight him and his allies - the British, the French and other Europeans.'' The Iraqi statement included a reiteration of Iraq's historical claims to Kuwait and Iraqi grievances against Western nations and Israel.

DOC.NOTE: For Release at 6:30 p.m. EDT. ^Incomes Declining in Third World Countries
DOC.TEXT: Incomes decreased in Third World countries last year but in places that did report increases, the rise was smaller than the year before, the World Bank reported. The bank's annual report, made public Sunday, also complained that military spending in the Third World has risen more than twice as fast as people's incomes and offered to help governments to curb it. No figures were given on military expenditures. The bank concentraes on what it calls low and middle-income countries. That includes most of the world: 92 countries with 3.9 billion people ranging in prosperity from Oman, where citizens had an average income of $5,070 in 1988, to Ethiopia with an average of only $120. It gave the average U.S. income for the year as $19,780. The bank found incomes a little lower last year in 19 heavily indebted countries from Poland to the Philippines - .1 of 1 percent. In Latin America and the Caribbean the decline was .6 of 1 percent, and .7 of 1 percent in a mixed bag of 22 countries in Europe, the Middle East and North Africa. Africa south of the Sahara showed a small improvement - .3 of 1 percent - after a steady decline through the 1980s. There were larger increases in South Asia - 2.5 percent - and in East Asia - 3.2 percent - but these increases had been considerably greater earlier in the decade. To help, the bank management headed by President Barber B. Conable is hoping to lend $21 billion to $24 billion in the 12 months to June 30, 1991. He has promised new emphasis on loans to reduce poverty and to improve the environment. The report did not accuse any specific country of spending too much on its military forces, but it contained some specific advice on military matters. Its leaders once considered the subject taboo. The old line was that the 151 governments who own the bank had to decide on military matters themselves. This report said spending on the military could be considered unproductive in general and was sometimes especially expensive for poor countries. ``Many countries with very low (individual) incomes devote a sizeable share of their government budget to defense - despite the fact that there are many pressing needs in other sectors of the economy,'' it said. ``Military expenditure has increased more than twice as fast as... income in the developing world since 1960,'' the report concluded. It said that as the world situation changes, governments will have to take a new look at their spending to improve the welfare of their citizens. That will include making it clear how much they have been spending on the military and how effective the spending has been compared with investment in education and health, it suggested. As the world's biggest lending agency and the biggest single source of aid money, the bank has great influence with borrowing governments. Last year it lent money to 79 of them from Algeria to Zimbabwe. Of those, 47 got loans that pay almost no interest and requires small installments over 40 years. Conable submitted the report Aug. 7, five days after Iraqi troops went into Kuwait. It covered events only up to June 30 and did not mention the invasion. But at a news conference last week Alex Shakow, the bank's director of external affairs, said the Gulf crisis should not be used as an excuse for military spending and that the bank was not giving up on the principle. The United States owns the biggest block of shares in the bank. The bank's management approved $20.702 billion in loans and made $1.046 billion in profit over the 12 months up to last July 1. In the previous year, $21.4 billion worth of loans were approved.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: peaceful end.''
DOC.TEXT: Bush pulled a paper from his pocket and quoted the Iraqi president's own words in a Nov. 28, 1988, speech saying ``An Arab country does not have the right to occupy another Arab country.'' If Iraq invaded another Arab nation ``We would want Arabs to send their armies to put things right. If Iraq should become intoxicated by its power and move to overwhelm another Arab state, the Arabs would be right to deploy their armies to check it,'' Bush said. Bush taped his eight-minute address last Wednesday after an Iraqi information minister suggested he would be given time on the country's television network, as Saddam Hussein has been by American television. The tape, including a voice-over translation and captions in Arabic, was ferried by a State Department courier to Baghdad and turned over to the government there by the U.S. charges d'affaires. The Iraqi ambassador in Washington had declined to take possession of it on Thursday, but assured Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger it would be shown in full on Iraqi television once it reached Baghdad. The Bush broadcast was followed immediately by an even longer response read by Saddam's spokesman calling it full of lies. The Iraqi spokesman said Bush was trying to become ``the dictator of the whole world.'' In his tape, Bush said he did not want to trade accusations, but explain to Iraq's people why the world was united in opposition to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion and occupation of Kuwait. He portrayed the invasion as yet another mistake by the same leaders who ``plunged'' Iraq into war with Iran in 1980. ``You've borne untold suffering and hardship during eight long years of war with Iran,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: National Guard: A Way of Life in Many Alabama Towns
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When Sgt. Maj. William Weston joined the Alabama National Guard more than 27 years ago, it seemed as natural as ... waving the American flag. ``I lived in a small town that was very much Guard-oriented,'' said Weston, a native of Brundidge, population 3,200. ``At the time I joined, my uncle was the company commander. It was the thing to do back then.'' As the nation's Guard and reserves play a major role in America's military response to the Mideast crisis, the call-up is hitting home. Alabama, with a population of about 4 million, has the largest Army National Guard of any state, with 21,700 members. Sgt. Norman Arnold, a Guard spokesman, said the next largest state force is Texas, with 21,400, followed by California, with 21,200. The two states both trail Alabama even though Texas has more than four times as many residents and California more than seven times, according to preliminary 1990 census figures. There also are 3,200 members of the Alabama Air National Guard, making the total strength almost 25,000 men and women, Arnold said. About 900 members from several Alabama Army Guard and Air Guard units have been activated since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. But the only Alabama guardsmen sent to Saudi Arabia so far are about 90 members of the 1241st Postal AG Company from Montgomery. Weston, who has been a member of the 31st Area Support Group in Montgomery since 1972, recalls how prominent the Guard was - and still is - in small towns like Brundidge, about 60 miles south of Alabama's capital city. ``In many cases, the National Guard armory is the center of town,'' he said, where dances, reunions and proms are held. ``In the small towns, we're the only military.'' Guardsmen usually sign up for six-year hitches and many re-enlist. Weston estimated that at least half of the soldiers in the 31st Group have more than 20 years of service. ``The day I joined up, there was six of us. We were all schoolmates. We joined and went off to basic training together,'' he said. ``Of the six who joined with me, I know at least three of them are still in the Guard.'' They go through basic training along with regular soldiers, then join the unit of their choice, perhaps in their hometown or one that specializes in a skill that will be useful in the civilian world. After that, guardsmen are required to participate in a 15-day training session each year, in addition to one weekend of duty each month. ``It's more tradition than anything else,'' said Col. Kenneth A. Blackmon, commander of the 31st. ``We have a lot of fathers and sons. I've got two sons in the National Guard. As soon as they were of age, they joined up.'' In Blackmon's case, the Guard helped pay for his sons to attend college - a luxury for many families in a state that ranks 43rd in per capita income. Also, the Guard provide job training in everything from electronics to truck driving. This is the first mobilization of the Alabama Guard for military duty since 1968, but guardsmen are more than just fighting men and women. They provided security and cleanup assistance after floodwaters ravaged the south Alabama town of Elba in March. And they were there when a killer tornado plowed through Huntsville in December. During the 1960s, guardsmen also were used to quell racial disturbances that erupted in many locales. Despite the outspoken segregationist stand of then-Gov. George C. Wallace, President Kennedy called up the Alabama Guard in 1963 to protect two blacks who broke the color line at the previously all-white University of Alabama. Lt. Cindy Eskridge, who graduated from officer candidate school in August, said she and others support President Bush's decision to send troops to the Middle East after Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein ordered the takeover of neighboring Kuwait. ``We wouldn't want someone to do to us what he did to Kuwait,'' she said. Other Southern states also have large Guard contingents. Alabama's neighbors - Florida, Mississippi, Georgia and Tennessee - are at 100 percent or more of their assigned strength, Arnold said. ``If you look at those states that have done well in their recruiting efforts for Guard units, it will run on a line from Virginia through the Carolinas right along the Deep South,'' Arnold said. ``Patriotism is still alive and well in Alabama and all across the Deep South.'' In Ms. Eskridge's case, she was ``bouncing around, not knowing what I wanted to do'' when she signed up four years ago. But her decision ran deeper than that. `It was a patriotic thing, a love of country. That had a lot to do with it, too,'' said Ms. Eskridge. ``It's not just a paycheck. It's part of serving your country.''

DOC.HEAD: Commander Accidentally Kills Soldier; Collaborators Attacked
DOC.TEXT: An army sergeant on patrol in a Palestinian village was fatally shot when his commander's rifle accidentally fired, according to military and newspaper reports Sunday. Three Palestinians were reportedly wounded, one seriously, in attacks on alleged collaborators with Israel. An army spokesman said Staff Sgt. David Baruch, 37, was shot Saturday ``by another officer who was on patrol'' in Kfar Malek, a village near the occupied West Bank city of Ramallah. He did not elaborate. Israeli newspapers said the accident occurred after the soldiers tried to catch youths who had hurled stones at them. The Maariv newspaper said the commander, a captain, had unloaded his U.S.-made M-16 rifle, but inadvertently left a bullet in the chamber. The rifle fired, hitting Baruch in the chest. Baruch was taken by helicopter to a hospital in Jerusalem, where he was pronounced dead, the Haaretz newspaper said. The captain, who was not identified, was being questioned by military police, newspapers reported. In the Bureij refugee camp in the Gaza Strip, masked assailants shot a father and son, Palestinan reports said. The reports said Khalil Abu Odeh, 53, was treated at a Gaza hospital for a bullet wound in the arm. His son, Atef, 30, was hit in the neck by two bullets and taken to a hospital near Tel Aviv. Israel radio said an alleged Palestinian drug dealer was stabbed by Arabs in Gaza, Palestinian reports said. Drug dealers are often accused of being informants to the Israelis. Since the start of the Palestinian uprising in Dec. 1987, at least 729 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis. Another 259 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs as alleged collaborators, and 51 Israelis and foreigners have been slain by Arabs.

DOC.HEAD: Canal To Lose 10 Percent of Revenue
DOC.TEXT: The Suez Canal, one of Egypt's main sources of badly needed hard currency, is expected to lose 10 percent of its revenues this year as a result of the U.N. blockade of Iraq, an official said Sunday. Mohammed Izzat Adel, Chairman of the Suez Canal authority, told the state-owned Middle-East News Agency that before the embargo was imposed in August, Iraq and Kuwait accounted for the annual export of seven million tons of oil through the canal. Their imports through the international waterway were also halted as a result of the embargo, imposed after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Adel said the expected decline in revenue was also due to the dwindling volume of trade between other Persian Gulf countries and western Europe due to the crisis. He said that volume of trade, about 40 million tons annually, may fall by 25 percent.

DOC.HEAD: One Of Tonight Show Veteran's Prize Chips Gets Chomped
DOC.TEXT: A man visiting a retirement expo spotted what looked like a tray of free samples of potato chips, so he took one and started to chew - and nearly broke Myrtle Young's heart. Young, 66, started a collection of potato chips that resemble famous people, animals and objects when she was a chip inspector at Seyfert's Foods Inc. She and her chips have appeared on ``Late Night with David Letterman'' and ``The Tonight Show.'' On Saturday, she had about 75 chips on display, including one that looked like a perfect sand dollar. ``There were quite a few people standing around, and I was telling them about my chip collection,'' she said. ``This one man reached through quickly and took one.'' ``I saw chips laying there as samples, so I picked one up,'' recalled Gregory Hough of Fort Wayne. Hough was quickly collared by a salesperson for Seyfert's and ordered to spit out what remained of the sand dollar chip. He said the chip tasted stale; Young estimated it was 2 years old. ``People will say it's only a potato chip,'' Young said. ``But Mother Nature makes these designs. We go through 250,000 pounds of potatoes in eight hours. To find something like this is so rare.'' Her favorite chip resembles a certain ski-jump-nosed comedian. ``Boy, I was so glad he did not grab Bob Hope,'' said Young. ``I keep him in a box. If he had grabbed him, I'd probably be in the hospital.'' As for the sand dollar, it cannot be repaired, she said, but ``I still have the poor, broken chip in a million pieces.'' But at least Young figures she got a story out of her loss. ``I told him that on my TV appearances, the next time they ask me if someone has ever eaten one of my chips, I'm going to say yes and tell this story,'' she said. ``Every time he sees a potato chip, he is going to get a sinking feeling.''

DOC.HEAD: Astronauts Disappointed but Defend Delayed Launches
LaserPhoto NY20 of Sept. 15
DOC.TEXT: They've spent months defending NASA's honor, reassuring worried family members and waiting for space shuttles to fly again. The men and women most affected by the summer's shuttle delays - the astronauts - are disappointed and unhappy with the recurring fuel leaks. But they're confident NASA is handling the situation well. Another try at a shuttle launch is set for this week. ``The folks in the office understand that nothing is 100 percent and that there's a risk involved. Since the Challenger accident, I think we've made great strides in reducing the risk,'' said Dan Brandenstein, 47, chief of the astronaut office. The mood around astronaut headquarters at Johnson Space Center in Houston comes nowhere close to matching the despair that followed the Challenger explosion on Jan. 28, 1986, which killed all seven on board. Twelve astronauts left that year, an unprecedented number. Still, it's the toughest time for the 82-member corps since flights resumed two years ago this month. Two of NASA's three shuttles are grounded by hydrogen leaks, and the flight schedule is in disarray. A shuttle has not flown since April. ``It's one thing if you have one mission that you had to delay or cancel because of a leak. But we've got several problems stacked up on top of each other,'' said Bruce Melnick, 40. He is scheduled to fly next month on Discovery, the only shuttle in which fuel leaks had not been found. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration hopes to prevent further schedule havoc by launching Columbia on Tuesday. The countdown got under way Saturday and was proceeding normally Sunday, NASA said. It will be the fourth launch attempt for the astronomy mission, considered by many astronauts to be ``snakebitten'' and part of NASA's bout of bad luck. At the same time, NASA has endured a searing stream of criticism from Congress and the rest of America for sending up a flawed Hubble Space Telescope in April on the last shuttle flight. For the astronauts, the verbal assaults hurt. ``Nobody likes to work for an agency that you give your heart for and then wake up with all this negative publicity,'' said Dick Richards, 44, commander of Discovery's upcoming mission. ``There are some things that are screw-ups and there are some things that you might call an act of God,'' said astronaut Story Musgrave, 55. ``It's the space business and it's the technology.'' That technology, as it involves leaking hydrogen, has been a main topic of conversation at the astronauts' regular Monday morning meetings since the leaks first were detected in late May. Columbia's seven-man crew, in particular, has been teased about the flight delays. Astronaut superstition holds that having an astronomer on board is an open invitation to scrubbed launches. This crew has four astronomers. ``See, it all fits,'' Brandenstein said, laughing. The standdown has been especially frustrating for the younger astronauts not yet assigned flights. The longer the delays, the longer it will be before they fly. ``We're all trained and we're ready to go. But we need to get the missions flying for us to get the opportunity to go,'' said Andy Allen, 35, a member of the class of 1987. The astronauts' concern goes beyond missed flights. Hydrogen is highly combustible and, if it leaked during liftoff, could cause an explosion. ``When it comes down to T-minus-zero and the engines are running and the solid rockets are burning and you're inside that thing, you want to make sure everything's in perfect condition,'' said Bruce McCandless, 53, who is retiring after 24 years as an astronaut. So far, no one has complained to Brandenstein about the delays or demanded explanations. ``I'd have a lot of people in my office if we had this leak and they said, `Well, it's not a big leak. Go launch it,''' he said. Before the Challenger accident, that well may have happened, Richards said. Now, ``the conservatism is there,'' he said. Still, being an astronaut means accepting risks and the fact that ``somewhere down the road, there's probably another accident,'' Brandenstein said. ``Obviously, we're working our fannies off trying to prevent that and make sure it doesn't happen,'' he said. ``But you've got to be a realist. There's probably one out there somewhere.''

DOC.HEAD: Saddam's Holy War Message Falling Mostly On Deaf Ears
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is having a hard time persuading most of his Arab brothers that they should unite under his leadership in a holy war against foreign invaders. Only in Jordan, the Israeli-occupied territories and, to a lesser degree, Algeria and Yemen has Saddam found receptive audiences. Elsewhere, the distaste for U.S. and other foreign troops facing Saddam's forces along Saudi Arabia's northern border with Kuwait is offset by an almost universal aversion to Iraq. Saddam so far has been unable to touch the Arab nerve that would bring into play the Egyptian proverb: ``My brother and me against my cousin. My cousin and me against the stranger.'' In a supreme insult, countries of the Gulf Cooperation Council, who saw member Kuwait fall to Iraqi tanks, are treating Iraq as they do Israel: its radio and television broadcasts are jammed. On Aug. 2, President Hosni Mubarak turned overnight from one of Saddam's closest friends into his toughest Arab enemy. Now it is difficult to hear a kind word for Saddam anywhere in Cairo. Last week, authorities invoked regulations requiring Iraqi citizens, as well as Palestinians, Jordanians and Yemenis, to obtain visas before coming to Egypt. The restrictions also apply to Kuwaitis, but a senior security officer said that was only to ensure Iraq would not sneak in agents posing as Kuwaitis. Also last week, Egypt's 20-man diplomatic staff left Kuwait for Baghdad but never made it back to Cairo. Authorities at Cairo International Airport then briefly detained seven Iraqi Embassy employees and their families trying to make their way home. And on Saturday, Egyptian authorities refused to let a leading left-wing politician and two leftist journalists go to Jordan to attend a pro-Saddam conference. ``Unity should never be achieved by force,'' said Mohamed Said Saeed of Cairo's al-Ahram Center for Political and Strategic Studies. ``We all know that the strength of Arabs should lie in their unity, but ... no one, I think would accept as leader someone who uses mustard gas against the Kurds in Iraq. ``If he treats them this way, how would he treat us?'' he said. Although no one in Cairo has expressed support for the Iraqi takeover of its oil-wealthy neighbor, many are opposed to the presence of foreign troops in the gulf region. On the day the leftist politician, Ibrahim Shukry of the Labor Party, was barred from leaving, Adel Hussein, editor of the party newspaper Al-Shaab, wrote: ``The deployment of foreign forces was essentially an American decision. ... Even if Saudi Arabia had refused to let these forces come, they would have come anyway, killing whoever stood in the way. ``Haven't you learned a lesson from (former President Anwar) Sadat's experience with U.S. aid? The first time they gave us aid to make peace with Israel. Today they offer aid to strike Iraq.'' That was as close as any Egyptians have come to publicly supporting the Iraqis. It is often coupled with anger that the United States opposes Iraq's occupation of Kuwait but acquiesces in Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza. But it comes side-by-side with denunciations of Saddam. ``Saddam's act is shameful and immoral,'' said Saad el-Din Ibrahim, sociology professor at the American University in Cairo. Nevertheless, he said, ``There is a deep sense of anger and frustration among the Arabs toward the Americans. They have double standards in their relationship with the Arabs and Israel.''

DOC.HEAD: Malaise, Cynicism Pervade Public's View of Government
DOC.TEXT: A not-so-funny thing happened to Bill Richardson on the way to re-election: he was jeered at a parade in his New Mexico district. The incident occurred a few weeks ago, during a procession in Taos. Normally, the Democratic congressman said, he gets thunderous cheers at such events. ``This time, I got some catcalls on the savings and loan issue,'' he recalled. ``People were not as warm and as positive, just in general.'' For Richardson, whose re-election is not in doubt, the incident was a concrete example of what pollsters and political analysts say is a widespread disaffection among American voters this election season. For now, the malaise has been pushed into the background by a preoccupation with the Persian Gulf crisis on the part of politicians, the news media and the public. But it has not gone away, according to political professionals. The feeling sweeps across the entire political landscape, they say, reflecting a general cynicism about the ability of government - local, state or federal - to confront and solve the country's problems. Were it not for the distraction of the gulf crisis, that would bode ill for incumbents at all levels in the Nov. 6 elections. At best, the situation makes for a volatility and unpredictability not seen in years, the analysts said. House incumbents, whose re-election rates have been as high as 98 percent recently, still have a formidable advantage over challengers. Members of Congress have at their disposal taxpayer-financed mail privileges, a staff to help solve constituents' problems, ready access to news coverage and an overwhelming advantage in raising money. But at the National Republican Congressional Committee, the party's Washington-based House campaign apparatus, polls show a steady erosion over the past two years in the job approval ratings of Democratic and Republican incumbents, said spokesman Gary Koops. And lawmakers who have been home recently are feeling the heat in a much less academic way. ``The American people are mad as hell,'' says Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla. ``It is real. People are angry that Congress isn't doing anything,'' he said, noting the savings and loan crisis, the failure to oversee housing programs that helped lead to the HUD scandal and the rampant federal budget deficit. ``Go to any town meeting. Republicans are mad, Democrats are mad,'' Edwards said. To Edwards' list of issues, political analyst Charles Cook adds a litany of additional sore points: the congressional pay raise, the proliferation of special-interest money in politics and the procession of ethics cases on Capitol Hill. ``The frustration voters have is, `We have some serious problems, we elected you to do something, and you're not doing anything.' It goes beyond just Washington,'' said NRCC chief Ed Rollins. But he said it is too early to say whether the malaise will build to the level of 1980, when several prominent incumbent senators were defeated. So far this year, only one incumbent House member has been defeated in the primary elections, and that was Ohio Republican Donald ``Buz'' Lukens, who ran for re-election after being convicted of having sex with a teen-age girl. But one indication of voter discontent is what promoters claim is the increased popularity of moves to limit the terms of state and national lawmakers. Three states - Oklahoma, Colorado and California - have ballot initiatives this year to curb the length of time legislators can serve. Terry Considine, a Colorado state senator who is pushing the initiative in his state, said the disgust with government is helping his campaign. ``There's a great sense that American government doesn't work very well,'' he said. ``Johnny Carson can get a laugh by saying, `We'll just let the post office handle that.''' Political operatives in 16 other states have contacted him to ask how to mount term-limitation initiatives of their own, Considine said. ``People are saying it doesn't matter who we elect. We can't change what happens. The system is broke.'' A nationwide poll in late August by Market Opinion Research, a GOP polling firm, found that perceptions and expectations of the economy had plummeted, and that fortunes of incumbents had fallen as well, amounting to ``an anti-incumbent undertow.'' In 1,000 interviews with registered voters, 44 percent said their representative was more concerned about getting re-elected than about solving the country's problems, compared with 41 percent who said their lawmaker was working seriously to solve problems. The margin of error was plus or minus 3.2 percentage points. Richardson said the crisis in the Middle East has even had a negative effect among voters who believe the government hasn't done enough to insulate them from higher fuel prices. ``Now I think you will find a high turnout of mad voters at the polls,'' he said. Added Considine: ``I don't think disenchantment with incumbency is a short-term or temporary phenomenon.''

DOC.HEAD: Design Problem Leaves Washington Airport Planners Up in Air
DOC.TEXT: Planners at Washington's National Airport are saddled with what could be a multimillion-dollar blind spot in their designs for a new terminal building. The master plan for the $200 million terminal, it was recently revealed, contains a fundamental flaw: one of the terminal's wings will block the control tower's line of sight to part of a runway. Airport codes require that the tower must have an unobstructed view of all runways. James A. Wilding, general manager of the Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority, said his office has been aware of the problem for several years and believed it could be handled with minimal adjustments. He said the ``ruckus'' only began in recent months when people seized on the design defect to urge major alterations in the master plan that would add up to $100 million to the cost of the project. Wilding acknowledges, however, that some members of the authority's board of directors were unaware until recently of the obscured runway issue. ``Obviously there was a communication problem.'' After several weeks of discussions, the authority is leaning toward relocating the control tower, a solution that will boost the price tag for the $735 million renovation project by only $15 million or $20 million and not seriously affect the scheduled 1994 completion date. Authority spokesman David Hess said focus turned to the blind spot this spring when the design team, led by well-known architect Cesar Pelli, started working out details for the 35-gate terminal. Wilding thought the dilemma was solvable by repositioning or lowering the height of the most northerly finger of the terminal. But some members of the board reportedly were concerned the low ceilings would be aesthetically unacceptable, and the airlines balked at changes in carefully worked-out gate assignments. ``The carriers were not in favor of that option because it doesn't provide equal accessibility to all,'' said Dick DeiTos, executive director of the Metropolitan Washington Airlines Committee. DeiTos said his organization, which represents the airlines at National Airport, learned of the line-of-sight problem about a year ago. That was far earlier than for some members of the authority's board. ``I do not recall it being raised,'' said Carrington Williams, one of 11 board members and chairman of the authority's planning committee. ``I was surprised at the magnitude of the problem when it was brought to our attention three or four months ago.'' One outgrowth of that revelation was a proposal that the entire terminal be relocated farther to the west, away from the runways. An advantage would be that the existing Metro railway station could then be included in the terminal building, rather than connected by an enclosed pedestrian walkway as planned. On the debit side, such a move would mean a two-to-three-year delay in completion and an extra $100 million in cost. ``The airlines would bear the brunt of it,'' DeiTos said, with much of the expense eventually passed on to consumers. The board in late August killed the new terminal idea. National, one of the capitol's two main airports along with Dulles, has been operating out of the same terminal for 49 years. With nearly 16 million passengers a year and an average 37 flights landing or taking off every hour during the day, no one questions the need for major renovation. There was also general sympathy for the authority's difficulty in trying to squeeze a new and larger terminal into only 90 acres of usable land between a highway and the Potomac River. ``In an airport as restricted as National, you've got to expect some glitches, and there probably will be more,'' said the board's Williams. ``There's not much room to wiggle,'' DeiTos said. Wilding said redesign of the northern finger and relocation of a taxiway on the affected runway are still being considered. But the final decision, expected in two or three months, appears moving solidly toward either relocating the control tower or raising the height of the existing tower on the old terminal. Even that would have to gain the approval of the Federal Aviation Administration and the National Capital Planning Commission, which oversees any alteration of Washington's skyscraper-less skyline.

DOC.HEAD: People In The News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: You might expect comedians to make jokes about lawyers - but would you believe a U.S. Supreme Court justice, even if he was partly serious? The problem with lawyers is they tend to make law far more serious and somber - and unintelligible - than it really is, said Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia. He was in town Friday to speak to the 92nd annual convention of the Colorado Bar Association. Scalia lectured them on the art of writing legal briefs. Briefs, he said, are ``a subject full of paradoxes, not the least of which is in the name `brief'. ... These things are 50 pages long.'' The legal term for the written arguments, he said, has its origin in the ``ancient Saxon word `braf''' and another ancient word with the same letters arranged slightly differently ``that means, roughly translated, to go on and on at great length until it makes you sick.'' A brief, he said, ``has two parts: a summary of arguments, and the arguments.'' Judges read the summaries, he said, so they should be written ``in English.'' The rest can be in ``legal English.'' Normal English will not do, he said. He said ``it is essential to legal English that one write as pompously as possible, using words and phrases that have long since disappeared from normal English discourse.'' --- WILSON, N.C. (AP) - Former North Carolina Gov. Jim Hunt suffered a broken collarbone, multiple broken ribs and bruises when a cow with a newborn calf charged him on his farm, hospital officials said. ``He is comfortable and stable,'' said Gail Reardon, nursing supervisor at Wilson Memorial Hospital, where Hunt was taken after te accident Saturday. He was expected to be hospitalized for up to three days for observation, Ms. Reardon said. Hunt, 53, a Democrat, served as governor from 1977 through 1984. He ran in a highly publicized campaign for the U.S. Senate against Jesse Helms, R-N.C., in 1984. --- EVENING SHADE, Ark. (AP) - Yes, Evening Shade is a real town, not just a fictional setting for Burt Reynolds' new TV series, also called ``Evening Shade.'' But there are a few differences. ``I like the comedy of it, but I didn't like the ideals of some of those things - drinking, nude ladies,'' said David Cooper, preacher at the Main Street Church of Christ. ``That's not characteristic of Evening Shade.'' The Arkansas Gazette arranged to preview the CBS series in the home economic classroom at Evening Shade High School. Twenty-seven people showed up, 8 percent of the town's population of a little over 300. Reynolds plays a cigar-smoking football coach in a small Arkansas town. His team hasn't won a game in years. The real Evening Shade has only a basketball team. ``And we don't ever lose,'' coach Robin Killian said. And townspeople agreed they would not tolerate a coach who smoked in public. The first show opens with a scene of the town strip tease artist streaking during a high school football game. Some scenes took place in a barbecue restaurant where people sip beer. The real Evening Shade is dry. But most residents said they didn't mind the series borrowing their town's name. ``Compared to the rest of the world, the morals around here I think are higher,'' said school superintendent John Walker. ``Something on the lines of the stripper and the smoking you have to take in perspective. People realize it's a comedy. We wouldn't allow it around here but it's just a show.'' --- CHICAGO (AP) - With her full, rich soprano and extraodinary sensibility, internationally acclaimed diva Jessye Norman has been able to put her stamp on a wide-ranging of nobly suffering heroines. Norman impressed critics in bringing the tragic title role of ``Alceste'' by Christopher Willibald Gluck to the Civic Opera House. The production had its Chicago debut Friday. However, the avant garde staging by designer and director Robert Wilson was not so well received. In the Sun-Times, critic Robert C. Marsh said Wilson's flying clipboards, an ominous cube bouncing on very visible wires and mimes instead of ballet dancers were odds with Gluck's perception of opera. Norman said she adored Gluck's opera, ``which is wonderfully written for the voice.'' Norman, who has built her career almost entirely on non-mainstream opera roles, said the script of ``Alceste'' was suited to her voice, which has been characterized as both soprano and mezzo-soprano. ``I want to sing what is comfortable,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Iraq Says Bush's Message ``Full of Lies and Contradictions''
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for digest item slugged AM-Gulf-Bush-TV.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's message to the Iraqi people was ``full of lies and contradictions,'' and a ``thundering rage'' is building up against the United States in the Arab world, an Iraqi TV commentator said Sunday. Mikdad Morad, the announcer who normally reads statements from President Saddam Hussein, also warned Bush that a showdown in the Gulf will end ``in a catastrophe'' for U.S. forces. ``Bush's message is full of lies and contradictions,'' Morad said. He spoke immediately after Bush's taped message was broadcast on Iraqi TV. Bush, in his message, told the Iraqis: ``Iraq stands isolated and alone.'' ``Saddam Hussein tells you that this crisis is a struggle between Iraq and America. In fact, it is Iraq against the world,'' said Bush, standing in front of his Oval Office desk with a U.S. flag behind him. ``Iraq finds itself on the brink of war.'' But he said, ``war is not inevitable. It is still possible to bring this crisis to a peaceful end.'' Morad, reading from a prepared text, responded: ``Should war be imposed on us, the Iraqi people will not hesitate in joining to teach the aggressor an important leasson, which neither they, nor their allies and agents, will ever forget. ``Your aggression,'' Morad told Bush, ``will end in a catastrophe for your forces.'' Morad, a familiar face on Iraqi television who was the only spokesman authorized to release military communiques during the eight years of war with Iran, ridiculed Bush's references to human rights and international law. ``Contemporary history has not witnessed worse violations of international law than those committed by the United States and its ally, Israel,'' he said. ``It is enough to recall that the United States has used more than 60 times the veto to knock down resolutions against Israel at the U.N. Security Council,'' he said, reapeating Arab criticism that the United States applies double standards in dealing with the invasion of Kuwait and the Israeli occupation of Arab territories. Morad said Bush was ``shedding crocodile tears for foreigners'' banned from traveling out of Iraq and Kuwait after Saddam's Aug. 2 invasion and subsequent annexation of Kuwait. ``They want to leave because of the embargo imposed by the United States,'' Morad said. He said ``Bush went crazy after Iraq entered Kuwait ... because he feared his oil interests were jeopardized, and not out of concern for the former Kuwaiti leaders, because he knows from what rotten background these Croesuses were molded.'' Croesus was a 6th-century B.C. king famous for his great wealth and his debauchery. Morad said Bush was ``naive when he tried to separate the people of Iraq from their leader.'' ``Our leader is the people's son,'' Morad said. ``This attempt reflects Bush's despair.'' He said the conflict ``is not at all, as Bush says, one between Iraq and the United States. It is one between the United States and the Iraqis, Arabs, Moslems and all the sincere people of the world. ``It is a conflict between right and injustice; between obscene wealth and oppressed people; between imperialism-Zionism and the deprived people. ``It is thundering rage in the Moslem and Islamic world against the United States,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Starts Monday For Winery Worker Charged With Seven Murders
DOC.TEXT: Ramon Salcido admits he shot, stabbed and slashed his wife, two young daughters and four other people to death in a rampage that terrified the peaceful Northern California wine country. Prosecutors say Salcido should die for his crimes, but the defense says the 29-year-old winery worker was in a ``psychotic depression,'' high on drugs and alcohol and legally incapable of first-degree murder. Opening statements in Salcido's trial are set for Monday, 17 months after the grisly slayings touched off a frantic search that ended with his arrest in his native Mexico. Two survivors are among the witnesses expected to testify in the case in San Mateo County Superior Court. Because of intensive news coverage, the case was transferred from Sonoma County, where the crimes occurred. ``I think that we have a straightforward case of seven counts of first-degree murder - that a man set out to and did kill seven people and tried to kill three others,'' Peter Bumerts, chief deputy district attorney in Sonoma County, said in a telephone interview. The prosecution will rely chiefly on Salcido himself. Bumerts said the jury will hear his taped confession to detectives, in which he describes the April 14, 1989, killings in detail. ``I think that statement indicates his premeditation and deliberation and that these were coldly calculated crimes,'' he says. Defense lawyer Marteen Miller said he will concede Salcido killed seven people. But the slayings, he insists, were not first-degree murder because Salcido could not have planned and willfully carried out the crimes. ``His whole world had fallen completely apart,'' Miller said. Salcido, ``infected with pride of almost psychotic proportions,'' was about to lose his job and his wife, who had found out about a previous marriage he never bothered to end or tell her about. ``He just went into a psychotic depression. ... And on top of that he became intoxicated and was using cocaine. All this was manifest in this crazy, bizarre and terrible tragedy,'' Miller says. Salcido is charged with fatally shooting his wife, Angela, 24, in the couple's Boyes Hot Springs duplex and cutting the throats of their three daughters and leaving them for dead at a county dump. Sofia, 4, and Teresa, 22 months, died; Carmina, then 2, survived, telling detectives, ``Dad hurt me.'' He also is accused of fatally stabbing his mother-in-law, Marian Richards, 47, and her 12-year-old daughter, Ruth, in their Cotati home; killing another Richards daughter, 8-year-old Marie, by cutting her throat; and shooting to death Tracey Toovey, 35, a co-worker at the Grand Cru winery in Glen Ellen. In addition to being charged with seven murders, Salcido is being tried for attempted murder in the the attack on Carmina, the shooting of co-worker Kenneth Butti, who was wounded in the shoulder, and the alleged attempt to shoot Butti's wife, Terri. The Buttis are among the prosecution's witnesses; Carmina will not appear, Bumerts said. Salcido told investigators who brought him back from Mexico within a week of the slayings that Angela Salcido told him their oldest daughter was not his. He also said that on the night before the killings the couple quarreled because he had been ordered to pay child support to a daughter of his first wife. Mrs. Salcido left the house after the argument. He said he then snorted three grams of cocaine and drank champagne before driving his daughters around, looking for his wife and deciding to kill his family. A note in Spanish was found in Salcido's abandoned car, saying ``Forgive me God, but this law made me do it. We could live better, me and my children, but what can I do.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection To Begin In Serial Killing Case
With AM-Winery Slayings
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection is expected to begin Monday in the case of a paroled child killer charged with the serial slayings of 11 women over the past 2{ years. Arthur J. Shawcross, 45, is charged with murdering 10 women in Monroe County in western New York. He faces a later trial in neighboring Wayne County on an 11th murder charge. The victims, mostly prostitutes or heavy drug users, were found dead from March 1988 to January 1990. Most had been strangled or suffocated, and their bodies dumped near water. Authorities have said Shawcross confessed to the slayings following his arreest Jan. 4 after state police spotted him sitting near a frozen body. At the time of the killings, Shawcross was on parole from an earlier conviction. He had served 15 years in prison for the 1972 strangling of an 8-year-old girl, and had confessed to killing a 10-year-old boy. Shawcross was never tried for the boy's death, and was allowed to plead guilty to a manslaughter charge in the girl's slaying. Although Shawcross had nearly completed his sentence when he was paroled, his capture set off a heated debate over the effectiveness of New York's parole system. Defense attorneys David Murante and Thomas J. Cocuzzi have said they will use an insanity defense. More than 3,000 potential jurors were called for the trial. Attorneys pre-screened juror questionnaires over the weekend, and County Judge Donald Wisner said he hoped to begin questioning of potential jurors in court on Monday. The judge said he hopes to have a jury selected by the end of the week. Murante said last month that he is worried about the effect of pre-trial publicity on potential jurors. ``You hope that people are answering honestly, that they have the courage and character to say `I can't do this,''' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Demand Gorbachev, Ryzhkov Resign
LaserPhoto MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of demonstrators marched to the Kremlin Sunday demanding that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his prime minister resign to take responsibility for the country's deepening economic crisis. ``The Economy is a Disaster,'' read banners carried by the crowd, which gathered under heavy rain at Gorky Park, crossed the Moscow River and then headed for central Moscow, where they listened to speeches just outside Red Square. The crowd of about 50,000 followed the same path taken by demonstrators earlier this year. Many marchers carried white, blue and red Russian flags from the pre-Bolshevik era, and they shouted ``Gorbachev Resign!'' ``Ryzhkov Resign!'' Participants in rallies in May and July called for the removal of Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov and the leadership in general. But the demand that Gorbachev step down was new. Ryzhkov and Gorbachev support different economic programs. The prime minister favors a more conservative approach to reform, while Gorbachev has thrown his support behind much of a radical blueprint for swift and dramatic reform supported by legislators from the Russian republic. Gorbachev, however, has been criticized for not implementing market reforms sooner. Soviets face shortages of food and many other products; store shelves are bare. Sunday's rally came a day after a leading reformer, Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov, said on national television that Ryzhkov's Cabinet should step aside for a government trusted by the people, the 15 Soviet republics and foreign nations. Popov said Ryzhkov had no real plan for reforming the economy. Ryzhkov, who appeared in a separate TV program Saturday night, defended his plan for moderate economic reform and said: ``we will stop at nothing to implement it.'' Ryzhkov and Popov were interviewed briefly on the evening news program Vremya, with longer versions played later on separate channels. Popov, who quit the Communist Party in July and favors the plan for radical economic reform drawn up by economist Stanislav Shatalin, said: ``the government did not have, does not have and does not want to have any real plan for a transition to the genuine market.'' He said Ryzkhov's government was responsible for the deplorable state of the Soviet economy, the lack of consumer goods and a growing deficit. ``We are sick and tired of empty shops and devalued money, we want no more crises,'' Popov said. Shatalin's plan, approved by Russian legislators, calls for transferring most economic authority from the national government to the republics, who then could move independently toward market economies. Ryzhkov's plan calls for keeping central control over the economy through 1991, and a much slower transition to a market-based economy. The rally also came two days after a constitutional committee ruled against a decree to give the Soviet government - rather than the Moscow government headed by Popov - the authority to allow or ban rallies in the center of the Soviet capital. Gobachev issued the decree in April. The official Tass news agency said the Constitutional Compliance Committee ruled Gorbachev's decree unconstitutional because it ``narrowed'' the powers of the Russian Republic - of which Moscow is the capital - and the city council, headed by Popov. The May and July rallies were slightly larger than Sunday's protest.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Delegation Arrives in Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A senior Iranian delegation arrived in Iraq Sunday, a sign of the growing rapprochement between the two longtime foes that could help Baghdad get around U.N. sanctions. The Iranian delegation was led by Manushahr Mutaqi, the deputy foreign minister for international relations, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus, quoted Mutaqi as saying issues including prisoner-of-war exchanges, border matters and the reopening of embassies would be discussed. The Iranian visit follows last Sunday's ground-breaking visit to Tehran by Iraq's foreign minister and deputy prime minister, Tariq Aziz, the first high-ranking Iraqi official to visit Iran in more than a decade. He was believed to have sought Iran's cooperation in circumventing the economic embargo imposed by the U.N. Security Council. In the wake of the Aziz visit, a source in the Iranian capital said Iran agreed to ship consignments of food and medicine to Iraq as ``humanitarian aid'' in return for 200,000 barrels of refined oil a day. The Tehran Times daily newspaper, which is close to the Iranian government, denied that last week. But Western and Arab oil experts have said they believed such a deal had been made. Aziz's visit was also aimed at negotating a formal treaty to end the Iran-Iraq war. A U.N.-sponsored cease-fire took hold in August 1988. The Iraqi official also said after his visit that the two countries had agreed to revive full diplomatic ties, essentially reopening the embassies in their capitals that were closed during the war. Iran's relations with Iraq have improved dramatically since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein withdrew his troops from territory occupied in the closing stages of the Iran-Iraq war. The move freed up tens of thousands of Iraqi troops for the confrontation with the U.S. military buildup in Saudi Arabia. The two sides have already repatriated thousands of prisoners of war and Iraq agreed to share soverignty of the Shatt-al-Arab waterway, the southern border between the two states. Iran has criticized the invasion of Kuwait, but has also become increasingly vocal in its attacks on the U.S. military deployment in Saudi Arabia. ``By nature, the presence of the United States in any part of the world will automatically create tension,'' Tehran's radical Abrar daily said Sunday. ``The U.S. presence in Islamic lands will bring nothing for Moslems but corruption and destruction.'' Also Sunday, 168 of the 270 members of Iran's Majlis, or Parliament, signed a document supporting Ayatollah Ali Khamenei's call last week for a holy war against the United States, Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency said. President Hashemi Rafsanjani also said any permanent stationing of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf region would be ``in no way acceptable,'' the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Tells Iraqi TV Viewers War Is Near Because of Saddam
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New throughout with additional quotes from Bush, Iraqi rebuttal
DOC.TEXT: President Bush warned the Iraqi people in a television broadcast Sunday they stand ``on the brink of war'' because Saddam Hussein misled his countrymen into invading Kuwait. Bush, in a taped message from the Oval Office, said, ``Iraq stands isolated and alone.'' ``Saddam Hussein tells you that this crisis is a struggle between Iraq and America. In fact, it is Iraq against the world,'' said Bush, standing in front of his desk with the American flag behind him. Iraqi television broadcast the Bush message Sunday evening around 7 p.m. local time (11 a.m. EDT). The White House had expressed skepticism beforehand that Saddam would let his people hear Bush's words. But the Iraqi president kept a promise to broadcast the taped message in prime time. ``Our embassy in Iraq monitored this and it appears that it ran in its entirety,'' said a White House spokesman, Sean Walsh. The eight-minute broadcast was followed immediately by an even longer rejoinder from Saddam, read by a spokesman, that met Bush's words of warning with a mixture of ridicule, disdain and defiance. ``Iraq finds itself on the brink of war,'' Bush said. But ``war is not inevitable. It is still possible to bring this crisis to a peaceful end.'' Bush pulled a paper from his pocket and quoted the Iraqi president's own words in a Nov. 28, 1988, speech saying ``An Arab country does not have the right to occupy another Arab country.'' If Iraq invaded another Arab nation, ``We would want Arabs to send their armies to put things right. If Iraq should become intoxicated by its power and move to overwhelm another Arab state, the Arabs would be right to deploy their armies to check it,'' Bush quoted Saddam. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, prompting the U.S.-led military buildup in the Middle East and a United Nations-sanctioned economic embargo. Bush told the Iraqi people Saddam had misled them. ``Saddam Hussein has told you that Iraqi troops were invited into Kuwait. That's not true,'' Bush said. ``Your own returning soldiers will tell you the Kuwaitis are fighting valiantly in any way they can.'' Bush taped his address last Wednesday after an Iraqi information minister suggested Bush would be given time on the country's television network, as Saddam Hussein has been by American television. The tape, including a voice-over translation and captions in Arabic, was ferried by a State Department courier to Baghdad and turned over to the government there. The Iraqi ambassador in Washington had declined to take possession of it Thursday, but assured Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger it would be shown in full on Iraqi television once it reached Baghdad. The Iraqi rebuttal called Bush's remarks full of lies. Citing Bush's call in a recent speech for ``a new world order,'' the statement said Bush fancied himself ``the dictator of the whole world.'' ``Bush was trying to fool the Iraqi people with certain words,'' it said. It offered no reply to what Bush called Iraq's ``barbaric'' holding of foreign hostages in Iraq and Kuwait. But it scoffed at Bush's words about the ``shameful'' plight of foreign workers stranded as refugees on Iraq's borders. These workers left Kuwait ``because of the U.S. threats of war,'' Saddam said through the spokesman. To Bush's argument that the world was united against Iraq, the Iraqi leader called it ``a dispute between right and wrong.'' The struggle pits ``the United States and its allies ... against Iraq and all Arabs and all Muslims and all believers in the whole world.'' And it said Bush was naive to think he could drive a wedge between the Iraqi people and their president. In his tape, Bush said he did not want to trade accusations, but explain to Iraq's people why the world was united in opposition to Iraq's invasion. He portrayed the invasion as yet another mistake by the same leaders who ``plunged'' Iraq into war with Iran in 1980. ``You've borne untold suffering and hardship during eight long years of war with Iran,'' Bush said. ``Once again, the same Iraqi leadership has miscalculated. Once again, the Iraqi people face tragedy.'' The United Nations sanctions against Iraq are meant ``not to punish the Iraqi people, but as a peaceful means to convince your leadership to withdraw rom Kuwait. The decision is in the hands of Saddam Hussein.'' ``No one - not the American people, not this president - wants war. But there are times when a country, when all countries ... must stand against aggression,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Led Fleet Tightens Noose, No Sign Saddam Will Take It On
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S.-led naval blockade of Iraq is squeezing Saddam Hussein, but the Iraqi leader has shown no sign he intends to take on the Western armada and shipping executives say he can survive without doing so. There are almost as many warships in the Persian Gulf as the 60 merchant ships that on average plow the strategic waterway each day. And more warships are on their way. Since the U.N. embargo was clamped on Iraq Aug. 6, four days after it invaded Kuwait, the U.S. Navy has challenged nearly 1,000 vessels and boarded more than 40. A merchant vessel is challenged every 10-15 minutes, either by warships, naval helicopters or the three British Nimrod maritime reconnaissance jets based in Oman, naval officials said. Shipping monitors report being overwhelmed by round-the-clock radio challenges to tankers and freighters. Only a handful of Iraqi ships have sailed from Umm Qasr, Iraq's main port in the northern Gulf, since the embargo was imposed. When challenged, the Iraqi vessels have backed down. ``Saddam Hussein is smart,'' said a gulf-based foreign shipping executive. ``Why should he risk provoking all that naval might, and risk a military strike in which he loses Kuwait, when he can survive with Kuwait in his hands? He'll sit tight.'' Earlier this month, Rear Adm. Jerry L. Unruh, commander of the U.S. battle group led by the aircraft carrier Independence patrolling the Gulf of Oman, also said Iraqi vessels were making no attempt to challenge the blockade. Baghdad, he said, seemed to be trying to wait out the crisis, avoiding anything that could provoke U.S. forces to take military action. The U.N. embargo has blocked all oil exports from Iraq and occupied Kuwait, cutting off an estimated 4 million barrels a day. Saddam has introduced rationing on some foodstuffs. Baghdad's Trade Ministry has halved monthly allowances of rice, sugar and cooking oil. But some experts believe Iraq has food stocks that could last several months. And neighboring Iran is reported to have agreed to allow ``humanitarian'' food and medicine shipments across the border in return for 200,000 barrels of free refined oil a day. Three loaded Iraqi oil tankers - the Hittin and Al-Qadissiyah, both 150,000 tons, and the 35,000-ton Rumaila - are reported to be moored at Umm Qasr. To get to the open sea, they would first have to sneak past British, and possibly French, warships that patrol the northern end of the Gulf. American ships patrol the southern end, around the Strait of Hormuz, the only way in and out of the Gulf. This arrangement, decided upon by Western naval officers last week, was apparently aimed at putting non-U.S. warships in a position to challenge vessels leaving Iraq, thus stressing the multinational makeup of the armada. The warships have been authorized by the United Nations to use minimal force if Iraqi ships resist challenges. U.S. officials have indicated their ships may shoot off the steering gear of any vessel that refuses to be inspected.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Protest Forest Bills in Congress
DOC.TEXT: About 500 environmentalists rallied at the Capitol on Sunday to protest congressional proposals they say would further eliminate the shrinking supply of the nation's oldest forests. The main group, Save America's Forests, voiced support for a proposal by Rep. Jim Jontz, D-Ind., that would prohibit logging in a forest preserve covering as much as 8 million acres of old-growth and some second-growth forests. The group opposes a more moderate forest protection bill by Rep. Bruce Vento, D-Minn., which last week passed the House Interior subcommittee. ``We are at a crossroads,'' said Mark Winstein, a spokesman for the group. ``The timber industry lobby has a national agenda as they grab the wealth of public lands, operating from a national power base in Congress.'' Winstein said he spoke for more than 30 organizations representing nearly 150,000 members in 18 states. The demonstrators sang songs, chanted slogans and toted banners calling for the preservation of forests and an end to clear cutting, a practice used to harvest all the trees in a given area. Leaders also criticized mainstream environmental groups, such as the Sierra Club and the National Wildlife Federation, for failing to take strong enough stands in political fights over the Northwest's old-growth trees and the northern spotted owl. ``They have a lot of muscle. We are asking them to flex it,'' Winstein said. Loggers and industry officials from the Pacific Northwest scheduled their own rally for Capitol Hill on Monday to voice opposition to pro-environmental legislation that would restrict logging and lock up huge tracts of old-growth forests to help save the spotted owl from extinction.
