Jackie Lang, state coordinator of the Oregon Lands Coalition, said about 200 industry workers and community leaders made the trip to help ``put faces'' on the unemployment figures used when discussing the cost of banning logging in Northwest forests. ``We're here now because our backs are really against the wall,'' Lang said Sunday. ``While we have been out working for a living, the radical environmentalists have been out working the system.'' Save America's Forests advocates an end to logging all old-growth forests as well as a ban on clear cutting and road construction in national forests. It also wants to include private lands in a new federal prohibition on exports of unprocessed logs from most public lands. Andy Mahler, president of Indiana's Protect Our Woods, said national environmental groups must do more to educate the public about logging on U.S. Forest Service lands. ``Most people still don't realize there is logging going on in national forests,'' he said. Tim Hermach, president of the Native Forest Council based in Eugene, Ore., said the world is united in a call to stop cutting the trees of the Brazilian rain forests. ``But the United States has logged 90 percent of its timber and Brazil has only logged 15 percent of its timber. It is hypocritical for Americans to tell Brazil to stop all logging,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Wants Equal Treatment If Congress OKs New Saudi Arms Deal
DOC.TEXT: Israeli Defense Minister Moshe Arens said Sunday he would ask the administration to provide his country with the means to match a massive arms deal being prepared for Saudi Arabia. Arens said Israel has not yet been consulted about the Saudi package, estimated to contain $20 billion worth of sophisticated arms, which State and Defense department officials are preparing to submit for approval to Congress. ``We hope there'll be a discussion with us,'' Arens said in a speech to a conference of the Washington Institute for Near East Studies. ``There is no one in Washington who believes this (the Saudi sale) could have a positive effect on Israel.'' Arens is meeting Monday in Washington with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. The United States is Israel's largest arms supplier, giving Israel $1.8 billion worth of weapons annually. If the United States goes through with the Saudi sale, Arens said, ``We would have to see what could be done to provide the necessary equilibrium'' for Israel. Arens did not elaborate. But Israeli sources say Arens intends to ask the United States for money to help Israel's own defense industry develop modern weaponry, in addition to U.S.-made weapons such as F-15 and F-16 fighter planes. Arens also wants the United States to provide Israel with access to its spy satellite photographs of Iraq and other Arab states, the sources said. Israel would like direct access to raw satellite photos but has received indications that the United States would not be willing to supply it, the sources said. Israel will ask for processed satellite photos or any other intelligence information the United States is willing to provide, the sources said. Arens said there was no way Israel could afford to pay for the amounts of weapons oil-rich Saudi Arabia is buying here. Instead, Israel will have to rely increasingly on its own defense industries, he said. Israel has already begun doing that in order to maintain its qualitative edge over the far larger Arab armies that surround it, he said. The need to boost the Israeli defense industries has become particularly acute in recent years because the United States has been supplying the Arab states with the same weapons they sell Israel, Arens said. Arens warned that the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the resultant arms sales to the Saudis and other U.S. allies were escalating the arms race in the Mideast and destabilizing the region. He said Israel would be willing to discuss a cessation of the arms flow into the area, if its Arab enemies did the same. The United States has asked Israel to refrain from intervening in the gulf crisis and has praised Israeli officials for keeping a low profile. Israel is maintaining a high level of readiness in case Iraqi President Saddam Hussein decides to fulfill his threat to attack the Jewish state as a means of uniting the Arab world behind him, Arens said. He praised President Bush for his ``remarkable`` success in uniting much of the world against Iraq, including Syria and Egypt. Arens said he hoped the rapprochement between Syria and the United States leads to peace with Israel, although he expressed doubts it would. Arens also plans to meet with Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and congressional leaders during his two-day visit to Washington. There were no plans for him to meet with Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Dole Says Allied Aid for Middle East Will Help Tough Budget Talks
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 23rd graf pvs, bgng: Foley, meanwhile, with 4 grafs to restate Carter's position and add Carter quotes.
DOC.HEAD: By LAWRENCE L. KNUTSON
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Senate Republican leader Bob Dole said Sunday that financial contributions by other nations in support of the U.S.-led drive against Iraq was welcome news for budget negotiators struggling to assemble a deficit-reduction package. ``We're going to score it one way or the other,'' Dole said of the contributions from such nations as Saudi Arabia, West Germany and Japan. Secretary of State James A. Baker III returned home from a 11-day trip early Sunday, his pockets bulging with $14 billion in new aid pledges. ``I don't know who gets the check. ... But we understand that it will have an impact on what we finally do in the budget summit.'' In another development Sunday, President Bush warned the Iraqi people in a television broadcast that they stand ``on the brink of war'' because Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait. But Bush, in a taped message from the Oval Office, said ``War is not inevitable. It is still possible to bring this crisis to a peaceful end.'' Bush's eight-minute talk was broadcast on Iraqi television, apparently in its entirety. The White House, meanwhile, applauded the United Nations Security Council's unanimous condemnation Sunday of Iraq's raids on the embassy compounds of France and other nations in Kuwait. ``We fully support the actions taken by the United Nations,'' administration spokesman Sean Walsh said. U.S. diplomats at the United Nations said the Security Council now would consider an aerial blockade against Iraq and secondary sanctions against nations flouting the U.N.trade embargo. Dole and House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., appearing on the NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program, said there was widespread agreement in Congress and across the country generally that the United States should not have to shoulder all of the costs of deterring Saddam Hussein. ``There is no question that there's a feeling in the country and in the Congress that we shouldn't bear these burdens alone, either the military side of it or the financial side of it,'' Foley said. But Dole, describing the initial response as ``certainly good news,'' questioned whether support will remain strong if it becomes necessary to keep U.S. military forces in the Persian Gulf region for an extended period. During his trip, Baker received pledges of $12 billion from three oil-rich Arab nations: Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and the Kuwaiti rulers overthrown and exiled by Hussein. West Germany extended nearly $2 billion for military aid and economic assistance to countries affected by the economic embargo on Iraq. Egypt and Syria said they would send more troops. Italy volunteered $145 million and a squadron of Tornados. Britain and France said they will send troops. The U.S. end of the military buildup is costing an estimated $1 billion a month. This enormous outlay is taking place as congressional and White House negotiators try to reach agreement on paring the federal deficit by $50 billion this year, $500 billion over five years. Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, interviewed Sunday on the CBS-TV program ``Face the Nation,'' made clear that the military wbuildup in the gulf is aimed at impressing Saddam. ``We want him to know we are serious,'' Scowcroft said. But he distanced the administration from comments by Gen. Michael J. Dugan, the Air Force chief of staff, who was quoted in Sunday editions of The Washington Post as saying U.S. military planners believed that if war breaks out, the only effective tactic was to hit Baghdad with massive air trikes that target Saddam personally. ``I would just point out that General Dugan is not in the chain of command and he does not speak for the administration,'' Scowcroft said. But he said contingency planning was developing ``for anything that might happen.'' Scowcroft hailed the recent increase in concrete support by U.S. allies for the drive against Iraq. ``I think it's a very heartwarming example of united action against aggression,'' Scowcroft said. Foley, meanwhile, disagreed with former President Jimmy Carter, who said the United States may have to drive Iraq from Kuwait with military force. ``I think the time is way too early to make a decision of that kind,'' Foley said. ``The strong support the president's had in the Middle East is based on the fact that he's been deliberate, he's been careful, he's been focused on the goals.'' Carter, appearing on CNN's ``Newsmaker Sunday'' program, said Iraq should be pushed out of Kuwait militarily if the punitive effect of economic sanctions do not succeed. ``But my hope is he will withdraw (and) accept a compromise worked out by the Arab community that will be easier for him to accept than a solution enforced on him by the United States and other Western powers,'' Carter said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Bloody Gloves Found in Slaying Suspect's Home
DOC.TEXT: State police found bloodstained gloves and a .38-caliber handgun in the home of a suspect in the stabbing deaths of five college students, a newspaper reported Sunday. But Edward Lewis Humphrey's grandmother said the blood and gloves found in a search of her home in Indialantic on Sept. 6 were hers, The Gainesville Sun reported. She also said the pistol has been in the house for years. Police said Humphrey, 18, is one of eight suspects in the murders of five students in off-campus apartments Aug. 26 to Aug. 28. Three of the students were mutilated, including one who was decapitated. Humphrey has not been charged in the slayings. He is being held in lieu of $1 million bond in the Brevard County Jail in Sharpes on charges he assaulted his 79-year-old grandmother on Aug. 30, shortly after he had returned from Gainesville, where he was a University of Florida freshman. He also faces warrants in an Aug. 25 assault on two male University of Florida students and an October 1988 armed burglary and attempted rape in Indian River County. Humphrey's grandmother, Elna Hlavaty, said the gloves found during the police search were stained with her blood when she fell and cut her head. When Humphrey was arrested, his grandmother told police he had choked her and punched her in the face. She later said her injuries were accidental and has asked that the charges be dropped. Lt. Spencer Mann, a spokesman for the Alachua County Sheriff's Office, refused to comment on the newspaper report Sunday. Mann said Sunday there are no major developments in the case and no arrests imminent. ``I am not expecting any major breaks any time soon,'' Mann said. The only other suspect publicly identified is Stephen Michael Bates, 30, being held in Polk County. He is charged with entering an apartment east of Lakeland and threatening a woman and her teen-age daughter with a knife. He is being held on $100,500 bond. A search of his home yielded a hangman's noose, two pairs of women's panties, pornography, satanic writings and a book on Jack the Ripper.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Researcher Sues Science Academy
DOC.TEXT: The National Academy of Sciences is fighting a $500,000 lawsuit that claims it plagiarized the writings of a nutrition researcher that it earlier had rejected. Victor Herbert, a lawyer and physician who filed the suit in U.S. District Court, charged that the academy copied figures verbatim on work he had done to update published recommended dietary allowances (RDAs), after earlier trying to discredit the work. ``Dr. Herbert is a great promoter of nutrition science,'' Herbert's attorney, Michael Botts, said in a telephone interview Sunday from Kansas City, Mo. ``It isn't just a moral point at all. (The academy) took his work and then went out and sold it. The academy made in the neighborhood of a half million dollars off of this work.'' RDAs form the foundation for determining the nutritional needs of schoolchildren, food stamp recipients and other federally funded supplemental programs. The academy sells lists of the standards to libraries, medical schools, doctors, dietitians and nutritionists. To update the RDAs in the mid-1980s, the science academy, an independent federal agency chartered by Congress, selected Herbert and nine other prominent nutrition scientists. Using a $650,000 grant from the National Institutes of Health, the committee's produced a document that discussed the sciences of each 18 essential vitamins and minerals that each person is encouraged to eat each day. Botts claimed the academy tinkered with the RDAs document before publishing it in October 1989, damaging the ``integrity of the authors' work'' and destroying the quality. The document included copyrighted material Herbert wrote on iron and on the vitamins B12 and folate, or folic acid, Botts said. Lawyers for the academy filed a motion for dismissal last week and a hearing on the motion has been scheduled for Oct. 17. The academy contends that if there is copyright infringement, the federal government should be the defendant in the suit, which was filed in February. Botts said the committee completed its work and passed peer review, and a September 1985 publication date was scheduled. The panel was prepared to recommend lower levels of vitamins A and C than what had been suggested earlier. But according to Botts, the academy gave the panel an ultimatum: keep the RDAs for vitamins A and C the same, while adding a footnote to the table at the end of the book. When the academy and committee disagreed over the wording of the footnote, the academy refused to publish the work and disbanded the group, Botts said. Botts described the disagreement as ``a conflict in nutrition between those who promote pop nutrition,'' such as those who call for high doses of fiber and vitamin C versus those who say there is harm in ingesting too much fiber and vitamin C. ``That's nonsense,'' Calvin H. Cobb Jr., a lawyer representing the academy, was quoted as saying in Saturday editions of The Washington Post. ``The complaint has no merit.'' The National Institutes of Health in 1986 told the academy it must fulfill the terms of the contract or return the money. Botts said NIH officials reviewed the committee's report and wanted it to be published but the academy said it needed $160,000 to select a subcommittee to update the earlier work. Meanwhile, Botts said Herbert's work appeared in a nutrition education journal in 1987. The academy published a 10th edition revision in October 1989. Botts said the subcommittee was listed as author, although the work included Herbert's writings.

DOC.HEAD: Zulu, Xhosa Leaders Make Joint Call For Peace
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos JOH2,3
DOC.TEXT: The king of the Zulus urged thousands of armed supporters Sunday to curb the factional fighting that has caused almost 800 deaths in black townships around Johannesburg. ``Everybody must lay down their arms and take their brother's hand in friendship,'' Zulu King Goodwill Zwelithini told fellow tribesmen in Soweto and Tokoza, two townships that have been hard hit by the fighting, which began in early August. Zwelithini shared the stage at the peace rallies with President Tutor Ndamase of the Transkei, the tribal homeland of the Xhosas. The Xhosas have joined fellow African National Congress supporters in clashes against Zulus loyal to the conservative Inkatha movement. Both sides blame the other for the fighting. But on Friday, ANC leader Nelson Mandela said South African President F.W. de Klerk now believes some of the violence may be instigated by a ``hidden hand,'' an apparent reference to right-wing whites and others opposed to de Klerk's efforts to attain power-sharing between blacks and whites. ``I have come to this place to put out the flames of violence,'' said Zwelithini at the two rallies attended by more than 30,000 Zulus, many wearing wearing red headbands and brandishing axes and spears. His speech was followed by a similar plea from Ndamase. ``Freedom is your goal, not bloodshed. Unity is your goal, not division. Power is your goal, not this bloody weakness,'' said Ndamase, who is Zwelithini's uncle. Following the rally in Soweto, a Zulu was injured after being set on fire by rival blacks, witnesses said. No other incidents were reported. Both leaders are considered ceremonial figures rather than political leaders, and it was unclear whether their calls for peace would slow the unrest. Neither holds an offical post in either the ANC or Inkatha. ``There is nobody who is entirely blameless,'' the king said of the fighting. ``We decided to come together to stand before the whole world to tell our people to stop this senseless black-on-black confrontation.'' Police initially threatened to disarm the Zulus. But the Zulus refused to give up the weapons, which they consider part of their traditional uniform necessary for tribal events. After negotiations, police gave in. At the rallies, chiefs dressed in animal skins mingled with youths wearing T-shirts with messages such as: ``Inkatha,'' ``Victory Through Peace'' and ``Don't Worry, Be Happy.'' The rallies came a day after police announced operation ``Iron Fist,'' a crackdown in the townships that will include roadblocks, sending in reinforcements and possibly imposing curfews. Police also said they would mount machine guns on armored patrol vehicles to curb the growing number of attacks on police in the townships. Mandela predicted the measures would be ineffective and claimed they were announced only because two white policemen were killed in the past week. The government last month sent police and army troops into the townships and imposed emergency regulations. Police reported the townships around Johannesburg were quiet on Sunday. The ANC and Inkatha, the two largest black political movements, both oppose apartheid but differ over tactics and plans for a future South Africa. The left-leaning ANC favors some degree of government economic control while Inkatha champions free-market measures. Under the apartheid system of racial segregation, the 5 million whites dominate politics and the economy. The nation has nearly 30 million blacks.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher First British Leader in Czechoslovakia in Half Century
DOC.TEXT: British Premier Margaret Thatcher arrived Sunday to begin a three-day visit to celebrate the collapse of communism and discuss the merits of private enterprise. Mrs. Thatcher, on a three-nation tour that also includes Hungary and Switzerland, is the first British leader to visit Czechoslovakia in more than 50 years. She was greeted at Prague airport by Czechoslovak Premier Marian Calfa and Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier. She also stopped to chat with Alexander Dubcek, whose Prague Spring reforms in 1968 were crushed by Soviet tanks. After receiving a military cannon salute, Mrs. Thatcher drove off to the center of the capital. She was thronged on the 11th century Old Town Square by thousands of well-wishers, some chanting, ``Maggie, Maggie,'' or ``Hello, Maggie.'' She had scheduled several private meetings Sunday before talks with President Vaclav Havel on Monday. ``The visits to Czechoslovakia and Hungary are rather by way of celebration and encouragement for the future,'' said a British government spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Czechoslovakia has a particular flavor because the people now running the country were all dissidents and people that we did our best to encourage. We did our best to maintain contacts,'' he said. A British ``privatization'' team arrived in Czechslovakia this month to help officials sell off dozens of state-owned enterprises. The Thatcher government has privatized most of Britain's former state-owned industries in the last decade, including its steel industry and British Airways. Mrs. Thatcher also was to address the Czechoslovak parliament and hold talks with Dubeck, the head of the assembly. She is to leave Tuesday for Hungary, which she last visited in 1984. Britain last year set up technical aid funds for Hungary and Poland. Mrs. Thatcher and her husband, Denis, also plan two days of official engagements in Zurich and Bern in Switzerland. Last week, French President Francois Mitterrand also visited Prague. Both visits, Havel said, were intended to ``put the final full stop'' to controversy over the 1938 Munich treaty signed by France and Britain, which preceded Nazi leader Adolph Hitler's invasion of Czechoslovakia. The treaty recognized Hitler's claims to the Sudetenland region of northern Czechoslovakia. Czechoslovakia was not represented at the treaty signing, and the country's diplomats were arrested after being summoned to hear the results of the conference. The territory was returned to Czechoslovakia in 1945.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Across South, Chilly in Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Rainy weather stretched from Arizona to Florida and up the Ohio Valley to Lake Erie on Sunday, and unseasonably chilly air moved across the Great Lakes into the Northeast. Showers and thunderstorms extended across southeastern through north-central Arizona, New Mexico, most of Texas, southern Louisiana, Florida and the coast of North Carolina. Thunderstorms over southwestern Texas had a potential for producing 2 to 3 inches of rain an hour, the National Weather Service said. Showers and thunderstorms also spread across eastern Ohio, northern West Virginia, western Pennsylvania and western New York state. Wind gusted to 64 mph during a thunderstorm at Cleveland, the weather service said. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 1.28 inches at Erie, Pa. In the West, showers and storms were scattered over the northern Pacific Coast, Colorado, south-central Wyoming, and south-central Montana. Unseasonably chilly air moved across the Great Lakes and into the Northeast and there was a chance of snowflakes during the night at higher elevations of New England, the weather service said. Advisories for frost were posted into Monday morning over northern Wisconsin and northern Michigan, and scattered frost was possible at higher elevations of southwestern Virginia, the weather service said. Frost advisories were posted for Monday night in the mountains of West Virginia. South of the advancing cool air, Cape Hatteras, N.C., tied its record high for the date at 87. Sunday's low for the Lower 48 states was 23 at Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 48 at Jamestown, N.Y., to 97 at Alexandria, La., and Fort Worth, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Attack Officals, Smash Ballot Boxes
DOC.TEXT: Voters attacked election officials and smashed ballot boxes Sunday, claiming the country's first multiparty elections in 22 years were rigged in favor of President Omar Bongo. One election official was reported hurt in the violence, which forced the closing of the main voting station in the capital city of Libreville. Sunday was the first of two rounds of voting to elect 120 legislators from 520 candidates in the oil-rich West African nation of 1.2 million people. Bongo called the election and legalized opposition parties following a wave of protests earlier this year. Bongo had permitted only his Democratic Party to operate since shortly after taking power in late 1967. Violence began after voters at the largest balloting station, Libreville's Hotel de Ville, said they discovered stuffed ballot boxes before voting began. They smashed the boxes and assaulted officials, witnesses said. At several voting stations in the capital, particularly in the populous suburbs of Lalala and Venez-Voir, election officials asked voters to deposit unmarked ballots. Shocked voters cried out that the elections were ``a scandal.''Journalists saw ballot papers that did not match the official forms circulating in Libreville. In Tchibanga, a small town about 300 miles southeast of Libreville, an independent radio station reported voters ransacked the election office and town hall and beat up election officials. The attacks there began after voters learned there were not enough ballots, and some of the 37 opposition parties claimed their tickets had been removed from voting booths, the station reported. The government did not immediately respond to the charges of fraud. It also was not clear if ballots would be counted or whether future voting will be held. Bongo's opponents accuse him of corruption, nepotism and economic policies that cause unemployment. They have promised better health care, education, housing and roads. Bongo, one of a handful of civilian leaders in West Africa, has said his party is ready to entertain new ideas. The Democratic Party already was assured of 13 uncontested assembly seats. The death of Progress Party leader Joseph Rendjambe on May 23 triggered widespread rioting by followers who accused Bongo of orchestrating his murder. The unrest ended after French and Gabonese doctors performed an autopsy and concluded Rendjambe, a diabetic, died of natural causes. The worst violence occurred in Port Gentil, where demonstrators burned down the French consulate and took some foreign oil executives hostage. France sent troops and the hostages were freed. Gabon, which achieved independence in 1960, receives about 80 percent of its income from oil.

DOC.HEAD: A Made For TV Wedding
DOC.TEXT: Live! From Centerville! It's the wedding of Todd Ruel and Laura Hutchins! Not every couple has a television audience for their wedding. But on Saturday, Ruel and Hutchins starred in their own televised wedding special from a cable station in Centerville, about 10 miles south of Dayton in western Ohio. The two were married where they met - amid cables and cameras - at the Miami Valley Cable Council. The event was broadcast live on two local cable channels. Ruel and Hutchins both worked behind the cameras at the cable council. Ruel is now a writer and producer for the TNT Network creative services in Atlanta. Hutchins, a scuba diving enthusiast, will join him in Atlanta where she's hoping to find work in underwater photography. ``I'm pretty nervous,'' Ruel said before the wedding. ``I know what goes on behind the scenes. But I'm not sure about the ceremony at all.'' Viewers were treated to a pre-wedding warm-up of sorts - 45 minutes before the ceremony, a video featuring the couple's ``formative years'' and friends discussing mistakes made at their own weddings was aired. Then Ruel and Hutchins exchanged the traditional vows, kissed, then walked down the aisle and out of Studio A. The guests applauded. ``The worst kind of event that anyone can have is one that's totally forgettable,'' Ruel said. ``I don't think this is that at all.''

DOC.HEAD: Retailer Spurs Revolt by Shoppers in Snub of Planned Parenthood
LaserPhoto MP1
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of customers of a department store chain are are tearing up their credit cards and threatening a Christmas season boycott in a revolt over the retailer's uncharacteristic snub of Planned Parenthood. ``I don't think they expected any big outcry,'' said Toni Tschann of the Minnesota Women's Political Caucus. ``And frankly, I never thought I'd hear from this many. But people aren't standing for it.'' Shredded credit cards began arriving by mail at Dayton Hudson Corp.'s downtown headquarters after the company's charitable foundation confirmed on Labor Day weekend that it was halting $20,000 education grants to Planned Parenthood of Minnesota, ending a 22-year association. The decision to end the grant came about the time the Christian Action Council of Falls Church, Va., said it would boycott Dayton's and other corporations for supporting Planned Parenthood. Dayton Hudson spokeswoman Ann Barkelew said the decision had nothing to do with pressure from special interest groups, but arose from confusion about the donations, which some misconstrued as support for abortion. Now the public response has prompted trustees of the Dayton Hudson Foundation to reconsider their decision and enter talks with Planned Parenthood that are set to continue this week. Barkelew said several hundred customers have returned their credit cards. On Saturday, about 500 people rallied outside a Dayton's store in suburban Edina and repeated their vow to boycott all Dayton Hudson stores beginning the day after Thanksgiving unless funding is restored. Dayton Hudson, with 1989 sales of $13.6 billion, owns Dayton's, Target, Marshall Field's, Hudson's and Mervyn's department stores in 33 states. ``Dayton's has always stood with women,'' said Gloria Griffin of the Minnesota Women's Consortium. ``Women are their customers. I strongly feel this is only a momentary mistake.'' Weighing in behind the irate shoppers is at least one big investor - New York City pension funds - and Bryn Mawr College President Mary Patterson McPherson, who sits on the Dayton Hudson board of directors but is not a trustee of the foundation. ``I am pleased they are reconsidering,'' said McPherson, who declined to elaborate. Dayton Hudson pioneered in 1946 a policy of giving 5 percent of profits for charitable causes. In 1989 the company gave away $22 million and received the America's Corporate Conscience Award from the Council on Economic Priorities. In addition, Dayton Hudson is on BusinessWeek magazine's top list of companies with ``women-friendly cultures.'' ``When a company of the prestige and importance in the philanthropic community says `no' to Planned Parenthood of Minnesota, that is a devastating message to corporate America,'' said Thomas Webber, executive director of Planned Parenthood of Minnesota. He said the $20,000 grant is financially insignificant compared to its symbolic importance. Elin Ohlsson, 35, of Edina, is one of many shoppers who believe Dayton's withdrew support from Planned Parenthood because of the threatened boycott by the Christian Action Council. ``When I was 18 I was raped and I needed Planned Parenthood for counseling,'' Ohlsson said. ``I feel betrayed by Dayton's.'' Barkelew said foundation trustees for years had considered ending financial support to Planned Parenthood because many people misconstrue the aid as support for abortion. Now the possibility of a boycott from either side looms just as the company enters the holiday shopping season, which generates more than 50 percent of annual sales. ``Our worst fears have been realized,'' said New York City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, a trustee of city pension funds holding $31.9 million of Dayton Hudson stock. ``We're long-term investors and it's quite clear that when people get angry with a company that can affect the bottom line.'' In a letter to Dayton Hudson Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Kenneth Macke, Holtzman and other city officials said that denying the funding places Dayton Hudson ``squarely in the camp of the anti-choice forces and in opposition to the overwhelming majority of Americans who support accessible birth control.''

DOC.HEAD: Refugee Airlift Continues
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A ragged line of 250 Bangladeshis burdened with boxes of grapes, flimsy luggage and unhappy memories of weeks in desert refugee camps boarded a Canadian jetliner Sunday for a flight home. The Nation Air plane from Amman to Dhaka, Bangladesh, was one of eight chartered evacuation flights taking an estimated 2,400 Bangladeshis who fled Kuwait following the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion. Jordanian officials said more than 219,000 foreigners have been evacuated on about 1,070 special flights since early August. At the same time, 37 cargo flights have brought in tons of food and supplies for the refugees waiting in camps for a way out. ``There are these C-130s that just come and go, come and go, come and go. ... It's an air bridge,'' said Royal Jordanian airlines vice president Akel Biltaji, whose company is helping coordinate the airlift. The tide of mostly Asian refugees overwhelmed Jordan, which has received about $19 million in U.N. relief aid. Many of the refugees ended up in squalid camps in the desert frontier near Iraq. The nation's news agency, Petra, estimated that 600,000 people fled to Jordan following the invasion. ``We were really amazed at the numbers, at the waves of bodies coming across the border,'' said Biltaji. A U.N. Soviet-built Antonov-124 unloaded 100 tons of rice at a remote corner of the airfield while its crew lounged in the sun. Later Sunday, about 450 Bangaladeshis would fly home aboard the aircraft, crowded onto foam rubber pads on the metal deck. A spokesman for the Bangladeshi consulate said six flights to Dhaka are scheduled for Monday to carry another 2,000 refugees. A Pakistan International Airlines official said about 800 Pakistanis would be repatriated Sunday aboard two jumbo jets. Biltaji said the government has flown more than 96,000 Egyptians and more than 1,200 Sudanese home from Amman and Aqaba, about 180 miles south. By midday Sunday, officials said 12,906 Yemenis, 30,254 Indians, 9,708 Pakistanis, 8,246 Filipinos, 9,547 Bangladeshis, and 29,688 others had been evacuated from Jordanian airports. Amman's Queen Alia International Airport, designed to accomodate 1,800 people at any given time, now can be packed with more than 6,500 people. ``Just think of it - here one has to be candid - just think of the toilets,'' said Biltaji.

DOC.HEAD: Islamic Scholars Ask Court To Disqualfy Bhutto
DOC.TEXT: Islamic scholars have asked a court to disqualify ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto from next month's election because they say she's not a good Moslem. Ms. Bhutto, whose government was dismissed by President Ghulam Ishaq Khan Aug. 6 on corruption charges, is a candidate for five of the 217 seats at stake in the National Assembly, the policy-making lower house of Parliament. Ms. Bhutto's aides say she wants to make sure that if she's disqualified from one seat she can still contest the others in the Oct. 24 poll. In this staunchly Islamic country of 110 million, there are separate seats for Moslems and non-Moslems. The lawsuit was filed against Ms. Bhutto Saturday in Lyari, a sprawling slum in central Karachi that Ms. Bhutto won in the November 1988 election. The seven Islamic scholars who filed the suit argued that a candidate for a Moslem seat must understand and practice the teachings of Islam and should not damage the freedom of the judiciary, defame the armed forces or be involved in corruption. The former prime minister, they said, did not fulfill these conditions and should be disqualified. They noted Ms. Bhutto had made statements in the national and international media against the teachings of Islam, a reference to statements that she opposed cutting off hands as punishment for crimes like theft. They asked the court to summon Ms. Bhutto and ask her to recite the Koran, the Moslem holy book, and answer questions about Islam. A hearing was set for Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Tells Iraqis They are Isolated; U.N. Weighs New Sanctions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 16-17, bgng `The Soviet...' to CORRECT that Soviet-Saudi ties existed previously, picks up 18th graf, `Two Tunisian...; ADDS new last graf on Indian ship being permitted to sail to Iraq; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY6, AMM1-3
DOC.TEXT: As the United Nations weighed new sanctions against Baghdad, Iraqi television broadcast a statement by President Bush Sunday in which he warned the Iraqi people their leader's brinkmanship could plunge them into war ``against the world.'' Hours later, thousands of men, women and children marched through the streets of Baghdad, chanting ``Death to Bush, Death to America!'' An official Iraqi response to Bush's statement called it full of ``lies and contradictions,'' and said the U.S. president aimed to be the ``dictator of the world.'' The U.N. Security Council, meeting in the early morning hours, unanimously condemned Iraq's raids last week on the French, Belgian, Canadian and Dutch embassy compounds in Kuwait, and warned that further sanctions against Baghdad were likely. Diplomats also began drafting language for a new resolution to close off Iraq's air routes and punish nations flouting the trade embargo, U.S. officials said. Bush's address to the Iraqi people, with an Arabic voice-over and captions provided by the State Department, apparently was broadcast in its entirety Sunday evening. ``Iraq finds itself on the brink of war,'' Bush said. But ``war is not inevitable. It is still possible to bring this crisis to a peaceful end.'' ``Saddam Hussein tells you that this crisis is a struggle between Iraq and America. In fact, it is Iraq against the world,'' said Bush, standing in front of his desk with the American flag behind him. The eight-minute speech was followed immediately by a 25-minute response from an Iraqi TV announcer. A ``thundering rage'' is building against the United States in the Arab world, and a showdown in the Gulf would end ``in a catastrophe'' for U.S. forces, said announcer Mikdad Morad, who usually reads statements from President Saddam Hussein. A group of a few hundred men later began marching in Baghdad. As they passed through residential neighborhoods, thousands of men, women and children joined them. Raising their clenched fists in the air, the demonstrators denounced Bush and also President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, whom they called ``traitors of the Arab world'' for backing the U.S.-led forces in the Persian Gulf. The U.N. resolution Sunday, along with actions by the Italian and Soviet governments, appeared to confirm a growing solidarity in opposition to Saddam, whose forces overran Kuwait Aug. 2. French officials rounded up for expulsion 26 Iraqi military trainees and three suspected secret agents. On Saturday, France said it was expelling diplomats and expanding its military presence in the gulf in response to the embassy raids. Italy also announced Sunday it was expelling all the officials at the Iraqi military attache's office in Rome. Other Iraqi diplomats were forbidden to go more than 18 miles from Rome's center without permission. Italy also said it would ask the European Community to adopt new retaliatory measures against Iraq. The Soviet Union appeared to take another step away from Baghdad, a former ally, with the visit to Moscow Sunday of Prince Saud Al-Faisal, the Saudi foreign minister. A dispatch from the official news agency Tass said he would sign a treaty re-establishing diplomatic relations between the Soviet Union and Saudi Arabia. The two countries have not had diplomatic ties since 1938. The most recent obstacle was the Soviet war against rebels in Afghanistan, who were funded by the Saudis. Two Tunisian newspapers reported Sunday that Iraqi troops had entered the Tunisian Embassy in Kuwait as well. In Bangladesh, the Bengali-language newspaper Ittefaq said soldiers stormed the residences of two embassy officials Friday. In Baghdad, meanwhile, a senior Iranian delegation arrived for a visit in another sign of a new alliance between the former foes. Saddam has sought better ties with Iran to get help beating the U.N. sanctions. The Iranian group was led by the deputy foreign minister for international relations, Manushahr Mutaqi, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. It quoted Mutaqi as saying he would discuss a prisoner-of-war exchange, border issues and reopening embassies closed since the 1980-1988 war. Sources have reported that Iran agreed to provide food and medicine to Iraq in exchange for 200,000 barrels of crude oil per day. Iran has maintained it will respect the U.N. embargo. But in any case, it has been reaping benefits from the crisis, making billions of dollars from oil prices pushed up since the embargo on oil exports from Iraq and Kuwait. Also Sunday, hundreds of Kuwaitis flooded into Saudi Arabia, telling tales of terror and anarchy at home as word spread that Iraq had unexpectedly opened the border for the first time in a month. The refugees, who began flowing through the Khafji crossing on Saturday, told of dwindling food supplies and Iraqi troops blowing up the homes of suspected resistance fighters in Kuwait City. In other developments: - A delegate to a conference of leftist Arabs, Islamic party members and Palestinian guerrilla factions in Amman, Jordan, called for commando raids against U.S. forces in the gulf. ``We are ready to join the Iraqi Popular Army as volunteers and to carry out commando operations against American forces,'' said Abdullah al-Hassan of the General Union of Sudanese Democratic Youth. About 150 delegates are attending the conference to oppose the U.S. presence in the gulf. - Chartered evacuation flights took 2,400 Bangladeshis home from Jordan. Since Aug. 5, Jordanian officials said, 219,234 foreigners have been evacuated. Thousands of Asians and other refugees have been stranded in camps in Jordan, awaiting transport home. - Six warships - three Canadian, two American and one British - entered the Suez Canal Sunday on their way to the gulf region, a canal official said. The American ships were the auxiliary freighters Cape May and Cape Mohican. - A cargo ship left India to bring 11,000 tons of food to 120,000 Indians stranded in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. Details about how to distribute the food - shipped under a special U.N. Security Council dispensation - once it reaches the Iraqi port of Umm Qasr were still being worked out, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: 6 Winning Tickets In $105 Million Florida Lottery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `None of...', to CLARIFY that winners' cannot validate tickets until Monday. SUBS 14th graf, `She said ...', to ADD payout for four of six winning numbers.
DOC.TEXT: Owners of six winning tickets will split a record Florida Lotto jackpot of an estimated $105 million, lottery officials said Sunday. Each of the tickets, bearing the numbers 5-6-21-34-35-45, is worth an estimated $17.5 million, said Lottery Secretary Rebecca Paul. The numbers were drawn at 11 p.m. Saturday, ending a week of lottomania in which more than 100 million $1 tickets were sold, sometimes at the rate of some 44,500 tickets a minute. The week followed four weeks in which there had been no Lotto jackpot winner, pushing the grand prize to its near-record height. In the history of state lotteries in the Unitd States, only a $115 million Lotto jackpot in Pennsylvania last year has been higher. In that drawing, 14 winning tickets were sold. With no single ticket holder taking home the $105 million this time, the U.S. record holder for a single winning lottery ticket remains Sheelah Ryan of Winter Springs. She bought the only lucky ticket in a $55.16 million Florida lottery drawing two years ago. Winning ticket holders in Saturday's drawing had to wait until lottery offices opened Monday to validate the tickets and begin the process of claiming their winnings, which will be paid off over 20 years. Some of the umpteen million losers had plenty to say, though. ``I just lost miserably,'' said Victor Morgan, who said he bought two tickets. ``But I've wasted my money on worse things.'' He watched the drawing at Sharkey's Shrimp Bar in downtown Miami. Jennifer Kram, who matched just three numbers on one of her 20 tickets, ``I'm very depressed. Three isn't good enough for me. I wanted at least $500,000.'' The three-number match will bring her a grand total of $5.50. Mrs. Paul hinted at the exhaustion the week had brought lottery officials. ``I think we're happy,'' she said at a midday news conference. ``I think we're glad it's over. But it's been fun and exciting.'' She said the estimated jackpot of $105 million - ``give or take a dollar or two'' - was based on last week's interest rates and total sales of more than 109 million tickets. Earlier, the jackpot was predicted to total $100 million. The six tickets were sold in New Smyrna Beach, Coconut Creek, Venice, Miami, Winter Haven and Longwood. She said there were nearly 2 million winners overall, including 1,581 tickets with five out of the six numbers. Those players will get $4,488 each. The 96,036 tickets with four of the six numbers are worth $108 each. Some 1.8 million who picked three of the six numbers will take home $5.50 each. The most popular combination was the simplest: 1,2,3,4,5,6. More than 52,000 tickets had those six numbers, Mrs. Paul said. Had those turned out to be the winners, the per-ticket payout would have been about $1,000, paid out in a lump sum rather than over 20 years. The jackpot for this week's game, to be decided Saturday night, was estimated at $9 million, lottery officials said. By law, half of every $1 spent on a Florida lottery ticket is returned to the players in the form of prizes. At least 38{ percent goes to education and the rest is spent on retailers and administration.

DOC.HEAD: Ed and Victoria McMahon Announce Marriage Dissolution Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Television star Ed McMahon and his wife, Victoria, announced Sunday that they cleared the final obstacle delaying their divorce. ``We have reached an amicable agreement to our mutual satisfaction,'' said the statement issued jointly by the McMahons through spokesman Lee Solters. The obstacle was not described and there was no elaboration. McMahon, 67, the ``Tonight Show'' sidekick to Johnny Carson and host of the ``Star Search'' talent show, filed for divorce on July 25, 1989, after 13 years of marriage. The couple has an adopted daughter, Katherine. After an October court hearing, Mrs. McMahon's attorney said McMahon had agreed to child and spousal support of $50,000 a month and shared custody of Katherine. The lawyer said the divorce would not become final until at least January 1991 because of a joint tax filing for 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Arabia and Soviet Union to Forge Diplomatic Ties
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prince Saud al-Faisal, the Saudi foreign minister, arrived in Moscow on Sunday and Soviet officials said he would sign a treaty re-establishing diplomatic relations between the countries, Tass reported. Prince Saud was greeted at the airport by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the state news agency said. The Soviet Union has been cultivating closer ties to moderate Arab governments, as well as to Israel. It severely criticized the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, formerly among its closest allies in the Mideast. Saudi Arabia and Moscow had full diplomatic relations until 1938, when Josef Stalin closed his embassy in Jiddah in a cost-cutting move. Several attempts to re-establish ties during the 1980s faltered over Saudi protests of the Soviet Union's treatment of its 50 million Moslems. Another sticking point was the Soviet war against Afghan rebels, who were supported by Saudi Arabia. Moscow withdrew its troops from Afghanistan in 1988. King Fahd met in December 1988 with Yuli Vorontsov, the Soviet deputy foreign minister, in the first high-level contact between the two countries in 50 years. ``The issue of establishing official contacts between the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Saudi Arabia has long been ripe,'' Sergei Kirpichenko, a Foreign Ministry official, was quoted by Tass as saying. Abdul-Wahab Abdul-Wasie, the Saudi minister for pilgrimage and endowments, attended an Islamic conference over the weekend in Moscow. Before leaving Saudi Arabia, Abdul-Wasie said he was seeking to consolidate cooperation between Soviet Moslems and religious circles in Saudi Arabia, the site of Islam's holiest shrines at Mecca and Medina. The Soviet Union permittted more than 1,000 Moslems to attend the annual pilgrimage, or hajj, to Mecca this summer. King Fahd recently donated about 1.6 million copies of the Koran to Soviet Moslems.

DOC.HEAD: France Expels 29 Iraqis in Retaliation for Kuwait Raid
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: France expelled 29 Iraqis on Sunday on orders of President Francois Mitterrand in retaliation for an Iraqi raid on the French ambassador's residence in Kuwait. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein sought to cool the French reaction, issuing a statement in which he said there was still a chance for improving relations between Iraq and France if Mitterrand changed his gulf policy. On Saturday, Saddam said Iraq would allow elderly and ailing Frenchmen to leave on Monday. Police in Lyon, Brest, Rennes and Rochefort herded 26 Iraqi technicians and military personnel, including four air force pilots, into buses and cars and took them under escort to Paris. The Iraqis had been in France for training programs at the time of the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The training programs were canceled and the Iraqis had been put up at hotels under close police surveillance. Three suspected Iraqi agents - all students living near Paris - also were picked up on Sunday by counterintelligence agents. The Iraqis were placed aboard an Air France jetliner at Charles de Gaulle-Roissy Airport, which departed for Amman, Jordan, late Sunday night. About 40 French police officers also boarded the flight. One of the Iraqis made a V-for-victory sign as a bus pulled up to the airplane, escorted by police cars and motorcycles. Iraq's Ambassador to France, Abderazzek al-Hachimi, observed the departure. The Iraqis were rounded up one day after Mitterrand ordered the expulsion of dozens of Iraqis, including 11 embassy staffers, the 26 civilian and military personnel and 10 other Iraqis whom the French president described as ``secret agents.'' Al-Hachimi said the 11 diplomatic personnel ordered to leave would depart on Friday. The French moves came in response to raids by Iraqi troops on the missions or diplomatic residences of France, Canada and Belgium in Kuwait City on Friday. Four French citizens, including the military attache, and the consuls of five nations including the United States were detained in the raids. The French attache and the consuls were released but France said the three other French nationals remained in Iraqi custody. As another retaliatory measure, Mitterrand said France will send tanks, warplanes, helicopters and 4,000 troops to Saudi Arabia to bolster the U.S.-led multinational force created since Iraq invaded Kuwait. Other European countries followed France in retaliating against Iraqi diplomatic personnel. Italy ordered all the officials at the Iraqi military attache's office in Rome to leave the country within 10 days and barred other Iraqi diplomats from traveling more than 18 miles from Rome's center without permission. Belgian Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens said in Cairo, Egypt, that the European Community would meet on Monday in Brussels to discuss retaliatory measures against Iraq. The official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus, carried a statement on Sunday by Saddam in which the Iraqi leader recalled the once-close ties between Paris and Baghdad. Before the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, France had been Iraq's biggest arms supplier after the Soviet Union. Saddam said Mitterrand had acted on the basis of ``inaccurate information.'' ``Regardless of the emotional content of the French government's decision, Iraq hoped and continues to hope and work to win France's friendship,'' he said. The Iraqi News Agency has denied the reports of violating diplomatic territory. The news agency quoted an Iraqi spokesman as saying a Frenchman, a counselor at the embassy, was found at a private house belonging to a female member of Kuwait's deposed ruling family. He was escorted to the embassy without incident, the spokesman claimed. The U.N. Security Council, meeting early Sunday, unanimously condemned Iraq's raids on the embassy compounds in Kuwait, and warned that further sanctions against Baghdad were likely. Diplomats began drafting language for a new resolution to close off Iraq's air routes and take secondary sanctions against nations flouting the trade embargo, U.S. officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Nice Mayor Resigns Amid Financial, Political Controversy
DOC.TEXT: After months of political and financial controversy, the mayor of this picturesque French Riviera city resigned Sunday to end more than six decades of family control in city hall. ``Endurance has its limits, and I've just reached the end of mine,'' read a letter by Jacques Medecin, 62, accused of improperly shifting funds to cover city debts and criticized for ties with extreme-right National Front politicians. Medecin's father, Jean, held the mayoral post for 38 years, except for a brief break during World War II. Medecin succeeded his father in 1966, forging a power base on the traditional right of French politics. Medecin told regional authorities in the letter that he would step down immediately. The job will be held by Assistant Mayor Honore Bailet pending new elections. Medecin, on a tour of Japan and the United States to promote the Riviera, could not be reached for comment Sunday. His resignation comes two months after the Regional Chamber of Accounts ruled Medecin, Bailet and three municipal councilors shifted city funds to cover municipal overdrafts. A mid-November court date was set, and city officials involved could be stripped of their posts if the chamber's ruling is upheld. Medecin also had been under fire by his conservative Rally for the Republic party, headed by Paris Mayor Jacques Chirac, for apparently courting members of the National Front, which supports an anti-immigrant platform. Medecin earlier this year appeared to be leaning toward an informal agreement with National Front councilors. Support for the party has grown in Nice. The National Front, led by Jean-Marie Le Pen, has the support of about 15 percent of France's voters, according to some recent polls.

DOC.HEAD: State Religious Protection Law May Hamper Prosecution
DOC.TEXT: A state law intended to protect children may hamper prosecution of a dead girl's parents for child abuse because of an exemption for parents who employ certain types of prayer healing. Angela Sweet died of a ruptured appendix on June 26 after her parents, members of a small religious sect called the General Assembly Church of the First Born, apparently decided to attempt to heal her with prayer instead of taking her to a doctor. David and Barbara Sweet of Olathe in west-central Colorado each face one count of felony child abuse. Their initial court appearance is set for Monday. The 1989 law calls for prosecution of parents who refuse to get medical treatment for a child when ordered to do so by a court, but no court order was obtained in Angela's case. Results of such prosecutions in Colorado and across the nation have been mixed. When a 14-year-old Grand Junction boy died in 1982 a week after his ppendix ruptured, then-District Attorney Terry Farina called a coroner's inquest. No charges were filed against the boy's parents, also members of the Church of the First Born. ``Contrary to most crimes, which are intentional with obvious motives, you often find loving parents who were parties to the death of their child,'' Farina said. In Boston earlier this year, the Christian Science parents of Robyn Twitchell, 2, who died of a bowel obstruction, were convicted of involuntary manslaughter. In Fort Collins, District Attorney Stuart Van Meveren is still battling a nine-year-old case in which the 5-week-old daughter of John Lybarger of Estes Park died of pneumonia while her parents prayed over her. Van Meveren won a conviction of child abuse, saw it overturned on procedural grounds and then re-convicted Lybarger after a second jury trial. The case has been appealed again. In Montrose, District Attorney Mike Stern agonized over the Sweet case for six weeks after Angela's death before filing child abuse charges against her parents. Complicating the issue are four visits made to the Sweet home by a social worker at the request of school officials. The social worker did not request a court order mandating medical treatment. ``There was a gap. They last saw her June 14 and she died June 26,'' said Stern. He did not know the reason for the gap. Montrose County attorney Greg Moxley is not allowing any social service representatives to discuss the case with anyone. John Mitchell, the Sweets' attorney, wouldn't comment on the case, nor would his clients. The 1989 law, whose chief lobbyists were Christian Scientists, was intended by its sponsors to guarantee a right to medical care for children, said state Rep. Dick Bond, the House sponsor of the measure. ``The bill had a criminal penalty in it originally because our intent was to stop something like this (Sweet) case,'' Bond said. ``But it came out at the insistence of Sen. (Terry) Considine.'' The Senate sponsor, Bill Owens, said Considine, championing parents' religious rights, weakened the bill considerably in conference committee. The bill says school officials, law enforcement officers, or others can ask county social service workers to visit a child they believe to be seriously ill. The social worker can then seek a court order mandating medical treatment. But a three-tier criteria designed by Christian Science lobbyists provides a loophole for some parents, said Owens. The bill recognizes faith healing as a legitimate medical treatment if fees are allowed to be deducted as medical expenses by the IRS, if fees are recognized as reimbursable by health insurance companies, and if the treatment has a success rate equal to that of standard medical treatment. Stern said there is still some question whether the Church of the First Born meets the exemption criteria. Considine, who says he is a ``believer in religious liberty,'' believes the social worker-visitor mechanism is adequate to protect children. ``I'm an Episcopalian, not a Christian Scientist,'' Considine said. ``I believe the state has a legitimate interest in protecting children, but what we didn't do is criminalize the behavior of the parents if they are operating under a religious belief.'' Since the Sweets were charged, elders of the Church of the First Born have been reluctant to comment, but last month they told the Grand Junction Daily Sentinel that members can seek medical care and repent later on. They also say children have a choice in the matter. ``She (Angela) believed and that's what she wanted,'' said elder Clyde Lewis.

DOC.HEAD: Skydiver Falls To Her Death
DOC.TEXT: A skydiver plunged to her death from 8,000 feet when her main parachute failed to open after an aerial stunt with other skydivers. Mary Jane Duncan, 31, of Highland, had linked with two other skydivers before they separated at about 6,500 feet on Saturday. Witnesses said she tumbled in the air as she pulled her main parachute rip cord. The canopy's small pilot chute, which fills with air and deploys the main chute, apparently became tangled as she tumbled, Jack Guthrie, owner of Cedar Valley Free Fall. ``I saw her pull her chute and only the pilot chute came out,'' said Dr. Charles V. Pledger, a witness. ``I knew the main chute was not coming out, and I kept waiting for her to pull her reserve chute.'' Duncan pulled her reserve chute about 100 feet above ground. Its rip cord handle was found about a foot from the body, said Mike Rawson of the state medical examiner's office. ``If she had done what she tried to do about two seconds sooner, there is a good possibility she'd have walked away from it,'' Guthrie said.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Chain Fired 30,000 After Theft Accusations
DOC.TEXT: Cumberland Farms Inc. officials fired more than 30,000 convenience store employees after they were questioned by company security for alleged theft, according to a published report. The Philadelphia Inquirer reported Sunday that records it obtained and corroborated in interviews with former employees showed that Cumberland Farms attempted to question 30,903 cashiers as part of a systematic effort to recover inventory losses by demanding money from employees accused of theft. Virtually all were fired, the newspaper reported. Fourteen former Cumberland Farms employees have filed a lawsuit, saying the company has a policy of falsely accusing cashiers of stealing and then threatening and coercing them into signing confessions. The company, based in Canton, Mass., denies the allegations. Cumberland Farms kept at least two sets of records on each employee questioned from at least 1976 to 1989, according to the Inquirer. One set of records assigned a serial number to identify the employee accused, and listed the reason for questioning, his or her employment status and whether the accused paid any money to the firm. ``Each person fired was given a number,'' Edward F. Breau, a former Cumberland Farms security official, told the newspaper. Breau said he left the company after refusing to question an employee without evidence. Since Aug. 1, the newspaper as reported that 275 former Cumberland Farms employees have said they were falsely accused of theft. They said that company security officials would take them into a back room of the store and threaten them until they signed confessions. The civil lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court in Camden, N.J., accuses Cumberland Farms of extortion, fraud, racketeering, malicious prosecution and wire and mail fraud. A spokesman for Cumberland Farms, Foster G. Macrides, said the company would not comment on the newspaper's findings because of the pending litigation. Three former Cumberland Farms loss-prevention specialists told the Inquirer that the company had a policy to coerce employees into signing confessions of theft, even though the company often had no evidence in those cases. Two of the security officials said they obtained confessions at least two-thirds of the time. Cumberland Farms is one of the nation's largest convenience store chains, with 1,200 stores and hundreds of gasoline stations in 11 states.

DOC.HEAD: Mine Workes Convention Begins with AFL-CIO Leader's Address
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,000 coal miners gather Monday to chart the future for the United Mine Workers, a once-powerful union facing legal troubles and declining membership as it marks its 100th anniversary. Delegates attending the convention at the opulent Fontainebleau Hotel will be asked to give the UMW's governing body, the International Executive Committee, new powers to combine some of the 21 districts and to use interest earnings from a strike fund to finance collective bargaining. ``Those appear to be the two largest issues,'' union spokesman John Duray said. ``But if you're looking at the big picture, the convention has to decide how the union will respond to changes in the industry.'' AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland is scheduled to address the opening session of the convention, the UMW's first since a special one-day gathering in Atlanta in 1986. The UMW rejoined the AFL-CIO last year, four decades after legendary UMW President John L. Lewis pulled his union out of the organization. Other speakers scheduled to address the delegates include the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole. The UMW, formed in 1890 by a merger of competing mine unions, once enjoyed tremendous power in a country dependent upon coal to fuel its factories and heat its homes, with its 400,000 members controlling 80 percent of the nation's coal output as late as the 1940s. But as the nation turned to natural gas, nuclear power and other sources of energy, and mines became more mechanized, the union's domination of coal began to lapse. Layoffs and an increase in non-union mines have reduced the UMW's working membership to 70,000, down from 120,000 a decade ago. An effort to merge the organization with the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers to create a national energy union fell apart in 1988 when the OCAW rejected the deal at the last minute. The union faces other problems. Although it won most of the concessions it sought during the 10-month Pittston Coal Group strike, the walkout helped cut the UMW's net worth by $45 million in 1989, down to $126 million. The union also faces $52 million in fines levied by a Virginia circuit judge because of the strike, plus more than $1 billion in lawsuits filed by coal companies idled by last summer's five-week wildcat strike in sympathy with the Pittston workers. One proposal union leaders expect to be put up for a vote would allow the 24-member International Executive Board to use interest from its strike fund toward the expenses of maintaining a strike, including legal fees and negotiating costs. When the 1983 convention approved the strike fund, it limited the money to paying benefits to striking miners. ``It's incredibly expensive to win a good contract,'' Duray said. ``The days when you could win a strike on the picket line are over.'' Another proposal would give the International Executive Board authority to merge districts, change their boundaries or dissolve them. Several districts have encountered financial problems because of coal industry layoffs.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Shout `Death To Bush'; Baghdad Says Bush's Message `Full of Lies'
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to ADD futher quote from Bush address, EDITS thereafter to tighten; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Iraqis took to the streets Sunday shouting, ``Death to Bush, Death to America!'' after President Bush said in a televised message that Iraq was isolated and ``on the brink of war.'' The demonstration came soon after an Iraqi TV announcer delivered a stinging response to Bush's statement, saying it was full of ``lies and contradictions'' and warning that a ``thundering rage'' against the United States is building in the Arab world. The rally first gathered a few hundred men. As they marched through residential neighborhoods, thousands of others, including women and children, joined them. Raising their clenched fists in the air, the demonstrators cried, ``Death to Bush, Death to America!'' They also called Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia ``traitors of the Arab world'' for backing the U.S.-led multinational troop buildup against Iraq. In Bush's message on state-run Iraqi television, he warned that ``Iraq stands isolated and alone'' following its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``Saddam Hussein tells you that this crisis is a struggle between Iraq and America. In fact, it is Iraq against the world,'' said Bush, standing in front of his White House desk with the American flag behind him. Bush portrayed the invasion as yet another mistake by the same leaders who ``plunged'' Iraq into war with Iran in 1980. ``You've borne untold suffering and hardship during eight long years of war with Iran,'' Bush said. ``Once again, the same Iraqi leadership has miscalculated. Once again, the Iraqi people face tragedy.'' The U.N. economic embargo against Iraq is meant ``not to punish the Iraqi people, but as a peaceful means to convince your leadership to withdraw rom Kuwait,'' he said. ``The decision is in the hands of Saddam Hussein.'' ``No one - not the American people, not this president - wants war. But there are times when a country, when all countries ... must stand against aggression,'' Bush said. His eight-minute speech was followed by a 25-minute denunciation from Mikdad Morad, the announcer who usually reads statements from President Saddam Hussein. The statement, though an official commentary, was not read in Saddam's name, as some past messages have been. ``Should war be imposed on us, the Iraqi people will not hesitate in joining to teach the aggressor an important leasson, which neither they, nor their allies and agents, will ever forget'' Morad said. The United States has tens of thousands of troops arrayed against Iraq in Saudi Arabia and elsewhere in the Persian Gulf region. The deployment began after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, and other nations have since joined the military buildup. ``Your aggression will end in a catastrophe for your forces,'' the Iraqi statement warned. As have past Iraqi statements, Sunday's response to Bush's message sought to tie the Persian Gulf crisis to other disputes in the Mideast. It repeated Arab criticism that the United States applies double standards in dealing with the invasion of Kuwait and the Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. It said the U.S. president was ``shedding crocodile tears for foreigners'' prevented from leaving Iraq and Kuwait, some of whom are being used as human shields to protect Iraqi installations against potential U.S. attack. ``They want to leave because of the embargo imposed by the United States,'' the Iraqi statement said. ``Bush went crazy after Iraq entered Kuwait ... because he feared his oil interests were jeopardized, and not out of concern for the former Kuwaiti leaders,'' it said. The Iraqi announcer said the conflict ``is not at all, as Bush says, one between Iraq and the United States. It is one between the United States and the Iraqis, Arabs, Moslems and all the sincere people of the world. ``It is thundering rage in the Moslem and Islamic world against the United States,'' it added. Bush taped his address last Wednesday after an Iraqi information minister suggested the U.S. president would be given time on the country's television network, as Saddam has been by American television. The White House had reportedly been irked by the amount of U.S. air time Saddam's views were getting. The Bush tape, including a voice-over translation and captions in Arabic, was ferried by a State Department courier to Baghdad and turned over to the government there by the U.S. charges d'affaires.

DOC.HEAD: American Tap Dancer Steve Condos Dies After Show
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to give cause of death; pickup 4th graf, `He gave...'
DOC.TEXT: Legendary tap dancer Steve Condos collapsed in his dressing room after a grueling performance Sunday at the Festival of Dance in Lyon and died. He was 71. Organizers of the biennial festival said in a press release that Condos died shortly after walking off stage at the Maurice Ravel Auditorium. Doctors at the Lyon coroner's institute said the cause of death appeared to be a heart attack. ``He gave an absolutely brilliant performance,'' his widow, Lorraine Condos, told The Associated Press by telephone. ``I was out front filming it. He walked off stage, went into his dressing room and collapsed.'' Mrs. Condos said rising modern dance star David Parson tried to revive her husband with cardio-pulmonary resuscitation to no avail. She did not say whether her husband had suffered any recent ailments. ``They couldn't do anything,'' Mrs. Condos said. ``But it was such a happy day for Steve. He was so happy to be performing and getting the recognition he deserved.'' Condos, a figure on the American stage for half a century, had been in semiretirement for years and had been greatly enjoying the reunion with some of his old colleagues from vaudeville days. The tapper won a huge ovation from a black-tie audience of hundreds of people when the festival opened Friday night with a gala show featuring Hollywood great Cyd Charisse. A central figure in the production, ``Stars and Taps,'' Condos performed a long, fast tap that left him breathless when the show ended about 2 a.m. Saturday morning. Condos tried to express his thanks to the crowd through a microphone but was unable to catch his breath. He then gave up and performed an encore. He danced again Saturday and collapsed after Sunday's performance. In an interview before he performed Friday, Condos had said he danced four to five hours a day ``because I just love to dance.'' Other old-time tappers at the festival include Jimmy Slyde, the Nicholas Brothers, Eddie Brown and Lavaughn Robinson. Up-and-comers were 16-year-old whiz Savon Glover and Sam Weber. Condos told The Associated Press: ``I'm enjoying tapping more now than I did as a youngster, when I'd be off doing a show in some club and the other guys would all be scattered around.'' A native of Philadelphia, Condos had recently lived in Hollywood, Fla., performing only occasionally. But the Lyon festival this year features many tap greats of his generation, and he decided to join them in a salute to the American dance form. ``We're all together, we watch each other and we even learn from each other,'' Condos told the AP. One of the few white stars in an art form usually dominated by blacks, Condos liked to lay a microphone on the floor to pick up what the called the ``power rhythm articulation'' of tapping shoes. Sunday had been scheduled as the third and final performance for ``Stars and Taps'' and Condos had planned to go to Paris to give master's lessons to French tap students. In addition to Mrs. Condos, he is survived by four children. Funeral arrangements were not known.

DOC.HEAD: Newspapers Hope to Find Uncounted Montanans
DOC.TEXT: The seven biggest newspapers in Montana asked their readers Sunday to help prove that the U.S. Census Bureau failed to count many Montana residents. Montana could lose one of its two seats in the U.S. House of Representatives because its population has remained steady since the 1980 census. Several local governments have already challenged the Census Bureau's preliminary figures, and the Montana attorney general's office is investigating some aspects of the count. Preliminary figures released at the end of August showed Montana with 794,329 people, a gain of about 7,000 since the 1980 census. John Murphy, manager of the district census office in Helena, said 817,000 people was the smallest number he had heard estimated for Montana to retain two House seats. Sunday's editions of the seven newspapers include a coupon to be filled out by any Montana resident who was not counted. The newspapers are the Billings Gazette, Bozeman Daily Chronicle, Butte Montana Standard, Great Falls Tribune, Helena Independent Record, Kalispell Daily Inter Lake and the Missoulian.

DOC.HEAD: East German Deputies' Demand for Money Angers Bonn
DOC.TEXT: A request from East German parliament deputies that their salaries continue to be paid after the two Germanys unify on Oct. 3 has upset West German political leaders, a newspaper said Sunday. Some West Germans interpreted the request as a veiled threat by the deputies to vote against the unification treaty unless their demands were met. The deputies are demanding that they continue receiving their salaries and benefits after East Germany's first democratically elected legislature is dissolved with unification on Oct. 3. The request came in a letter by East German parliament Speaker Sabine Bergmann-Pohl to West German leaders, including Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The East German deputies want to be paid at least until all-German elections are held on Dec. 2. They receive a monthly salary of $3,750 and such a move would cost West German taxpayers, already worried about the soaring cost of unification, about $1.9 million. Mrs. Bergmann-Pohl's letter was published on Sunday by the West German newspaper Bild am Sonntag. ``East German Deputies Blackmail Kohl,'' the newspaper's front-page headline said. After unification, 144 deputies from the 400-member East German parliament, or Volkskammer, will be integrated into the West German Bundestag until the elections for a united parliament are held. The other 256 deputies will lose their seats. ``This different treatment is causing strong unrest in the Volkskammer,'' Mrs. Bergmann-Pohl's letter said. ``The resulting anger is leading to uncertainty about the vote on the unification treaty.'' The Volkskammer is scheduled to vote on Thursday, and a two-thirds majority is needed. Bild am Sonntag said Kohl and Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble were angered by the request and would reject it. Officials of other political parties also criticized Mrs. Bergmann-Pohl's letter. She said on Sunday that her letter had been misunderstood and that she had only asked that deputies not going to the Bundestag keep their ``status'' until Dec. 2. In an interview with the newspaper Bild released in advance of its publication Monday, she said deputies who may not have jobs to return to should receive severance pay for their service in the Volkskammer. An Interior Ministry spokesman in Bonn said Sunday that it was legally impossible for Volkskammer members not going to the Bundestag to retain their deputy's status after Oct. 3. But he said officials from the two states would discuss on Monday possibilities for giving the outgoing deputies severance pay.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Opens Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar opened at 136.45 yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market Monday, down from Friday's close of 136.55 yen.

DOC.HEAD: Gainsborough and Reynolds Paintings Stolen
DOC.TEXT: Two portraits by Thomas Gainsborough and one by Sir Joshua Reynolds, together worth $11 million, were stolen Sunday from a law office complex, police said. Scotland Yad police headquarters said a guard told them a man had hit him in the face and knocked him out. His hands were tied behind his back and his keys stolen. The canvases were cut from their frames. Lincon's Inn, the law office complex, estimated their value at $3.7 million each. William Pitt, who became prime minister at age 24 in 1783, is the subject of one of the Gainsboroughs, painted full length when Pitt was 20. The other Gainsborough is a full-length of Judge Sir John Skinner in red robe and wig. The Reynolds is a head and shoulders portrait of Francis Hargrave, a treasurer of the Inn. Lincoln's Inn and the adjoining Lincoln's Inn Fields comprise a large, peaceful complex with trees, gardens, tennis and basketball courts, where many lawyers have their offices. The Great Hall is used for dining by judges and barristers. The Inn, founded in the 14th century, is one of the four Inns of Court that have the power of calling law students to the English Bar. They then become barristers with the right to plead in superior courts. Charles Dickens worked in Lincoln's Inn as an office boy at the Court of Chancery, an experience that gave him the experience to depict it with venom in his novel ``Bleak House.''

DOC.HEAD: Toddler Pulled From Shaft Released from Hospital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, `Kevin was..., with 2 grafs to UPDATE boy's release from hospital, quotes. DELETES now redundant 6th graf pvs, ```Kevin appeared.... Picks up 7th graf pvs, `The ordeal...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DX1,DX2
DOC.TEXT: A toddler trapped for 14 hours in a shaft dug for a remodeling project busied himself making mud balls and listening to his mother's repertoire of nursery songs before rescuers reached him at dawn. ``It was really difficult. I could hear him crying, but I couldn't touch him and I couldn't help him,'' Lisa Davis, the mother of 20-month-old Kevin, said while fighting back tears at a news conference at Denver General Hospital on Sunday. The team of rescuers cheered when the boy was brought to the surface shortly after 6 a.m Sunday. ``When he clinched my fingers, I felt a tingle in my heart,'' said firefighter Joe Cipri, who pulled him out. ``It's still there.''
