Kevin was treated for dehydration at the hospital and released Sunday afternoon, spokeswoman Mary Lee Chin said. ``His bruises were minimal,'' Chin said. ``There was no need to keep him in because he was doing great. As a matter of fact, I caught him jumping up and down on his bed this afternoon, so he's doing fine.'' The ordeal started about 4 p.m. Saturday when the toddler fell into a hole 18 inches wide and 12 feet deep dug for a remodeling project in a house the family was renovating in an upscale neighborhood in southeastern Denver. ``He wasn't playing in the room. He just came to visit for a second because it's not a safe place for a kid to be,'' said Kevin's father, Tom. ``He managed to slip under a piece of wood and fell into the hole. I heard him bouncing around in the hole.'' Firefighters from four metropolitan departments worked through the night to keep the boy warm and dry, pumping oxygen into the hole and shining the lights to keep the temperature at about 70 degrees. Mrs. Davis, 32, said Kevin kept himself amused by rolling mud into balls with his fingers and spinning himself around in the hole. Rescue workers dug a vertical shaft using a ``Vac-Hoe,'' a huge digger that excavates with a stream of compressed air and then vacuums out the loose dirt. They then delicately dug a horizontal tunnel across the five feet of earth where Kevin was. Mrs. Davis said she didn't say anything to her dirty, blond-haired son when he was brought up from the shaft, cradled in a splint-like device that protected his head, neck and upper body. ``I just wanted to hold him,'' she said. ``He's a pretty incredible boy.'' The couple said Kevin, their only child, was talkative and asked for a toy as soon as he arrived at the hospital. The incident was reminiscent of the October 1987 ordeal of Jessica McClure, the 18-month-old toddler who spent 58 hours in a well in Midland, Texas. The arduous effort to free her gripped the nation and her final emergence safe in the arms of rescue workers was televised nationally. Hearing about Kevin's predicament Saturday evening, Jessica's father, Chip McClure, said, ``I know every hour seems like a day. You have to have faith in the Lord. I'm sure their little boy will be all right.'' ``I'm really upset,'' he told the Rocky Mountain News. ``The pain I felt after Jessica fell down the well - I hate to see anybody have to go through that.'' Davis, 33, who would not divulge his occupation, said he did not have a building permit for the shaft, dug to reinforce the house. The couple were renovating the house, but were not living there. They declined to say where they currently live. Davis also refused to say why he did not obtain a building permit. ``But I do know what I'll be doing Monday morning,'' he said. A Denver police spokeswoman who refused to give her name said Sunday that no decision had been made on possible charges against the Davises for the lack of a building permit. Asked if they would tell their son about the ordeal, Mrs. Davis said: ``I think that sort of depends on what he says to us and how he reacts. We plan to explain it truthfully and accurately and tell him the whole story,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Tanker Explodes in Michigan's Saginaw River
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 19th graf to UPDATE with three crew members admitted to hospital. CORRECTS that police report of heart attack was wrong.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BAY1
DOC.TEXT: A tanker carrying about 1 million gallons of gasoline exploded and burned Sunday on the Saginaw River, injuring most of the 18 people aboard and spilling fuel in the water. The fire was too hot for firefighters to douse, and officials waited for it to burn itself out, said Coast Guard Lt. Tom Koontz. One person from the ship was missing, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Gerald Backus. Gov. James Blanchard visited the site and declared the blaze an emergency, freeing state aid and assistance. The fire was reported at 8:45 a.m., while the tanker was unloading at the Total Refinery Dock Facility, and was still burning Sunday evening. Authorities warned spectators to clear the area in case of multiple explosions. ``A few people blew right off the boat and slammed ashore,'' said Bay City police Officer Kenneth Adcock. ``The sky is covered with black smoke. If it blows again, it's going to be a big one.'' Witnesses said the black smoke blocked out the sun throughout the afternoon. The tanker, owned by Cleveland Tankers Inc. of Cleveland, was carrying about 20,000 barrels of gasoline or about 1 million gallons, said Koontz. It has a capacity of about 54,000 barrels. ``That's the estimate. That's a lot of gas,'' Koontz said. The state Department of Natural Resources was conducting water and air pollution tests Sunday to check for environmental contamination, spokeswoman Susan Henry said. A gasoline spill is less damaging than an oil spill because ``it's volatile and it evaporates,'' she said, adding that two booms were strung downstream from the ship to contain any spilled fuel. Ronald Stopyak had returned home 15 minutes before the blast from working at the Bay Chemicals Co. directly across the river from the tanker. He said he raced back to work after hearing the explosion. ``I thought the plant exploded and when I got out there I saw black smoke everywhere,'' he said. ``I saw the employees on the ship go overboard. ``It was really hot. I could feel the heat from across the river.'' His wife, Cheryl, said their house is less than two blocks from the explosion and was shaken. ``It was like a slow rumbling, it got louder and louder like thunder,'' she said. Two Coast Guard helicopters sprayed fire-fighting foam while they rescued crew members from the tanker, said Lt. Dennis Secor. Coast Guard crews secured the tanker with cables to prevent it from drifting into a nearby bridge, he said. Bay Medical Center spokesman Curt Miller said three of the 17 crew members treated there were admitted. Two had head injuries, a third suffered chest pains. Police initially reported that one victim had suffered a heart attack. Bay City is a town of 40,000 on Lake Huron's Saginaw Bay, about 100 miles northwest of Detroit. The 380-foot tanker Jupiter was hauling unleaded gas from a Canadian port to the terminal, said Roger Schrum, a spokesman for the Ashland Oil Inc., of Ashland, Ky., which owns Cleveland Tankers. The Jupiter, built in 1976 in Jennings, La., is a double-lined tanker with six storage compartments, Schrum said.

DOC.HEAD: Rescuers Find Downed Plane's Life Raft
DOC.TEXT: Searchers Sunday evening discovered what appeared to be a half-submerged life raft in the North Atlantic near where a jetliner with 16 aboard was believed to have ditched last week. Officials said it appeared there were no survivors. A Canadian Forces Buffalo airplane spotted what was believed to be the Boeing 727's 24-man life raft, said Capt. Ross Brown of the Halifax search and rescue coordination center. The Canadian warship Nipigon was steaming to the area late Sunday, he said. The plane, owned by Faucett Airlines of Peru, was leased by Air Malta and was carrying airline employees and their families. It was en route from the Mediterranean island of Malta to Miami when it disappeared last Tuesday. Its last contact came before a routine refueling stop in Gander, Newfoundland, when the pilot reported a low-fuel emergency and said he was preparing to ditch in the ocean. Searchers ``located an international orange life raft, partially submerged,'' said Bob Norburn, a private radio operator monitoring transmissions between aircraft and the Nipigon, which was coordinating the sea search. ``There were no signs of life. ... No transmissions,'' he said. The sighting came several hours after officials confirmed a Soviet trawler's sighting of a section of the airliner's fuselage on Friday. ``The object was described as being cigar-shaped, grey in color with red and white stripes,'' Brown said. ``From the captain's description, officials have confirmed that the object is part of the aircraft fuselage.'' In a statement issued earlier Sunday evening, Brown said the jet probably broke up on impact. The Soviet trawler captain reported seeing the fuselage section floating about 240 miles south of Newfoundland. The jet, owned by Faucett Airlines of Peru and based in Miami, was leased by Air Malta.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan in Moscow, Will Meet With Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan toured the cathedrals of Leningrad Sunday before flying to Moscow, where he was to talk with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and address the national parliament. Reagan was greeted at the Moscow airport by U.S. Ambassador Jack Matlock and former Soviet ambassador Anatoly Dobrynin. Sunday was the second day of his five-day visit to the Soviet Union. Reagan was to meet with Gorbachev at the Kremlin on Monday and address members of the Supreme Soviet. On Tuesday, he was to meet with students of Moscow State University. Reagan and his wife, Nancy, are on a 10-day European tour. He flies to Rome at the conclusion of his Soviet visit.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Violinist Wins Gold Medal at International Tourney
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Pavel Berman won the gold medal at the International Violin Competition on Sunday, earning a Carnegie Hall debut and $22,000. Berman, 20, is the son of Soviet pianist Lazar Berman. The Moscow native also won a European management contract, more than 50 recital engagements with major North American orchestras and a gold watch. ``You play from heart to heart in Russia. You speak from your heart and soul,'' Berman said. The first-place finish ``is my chance, my chance to make my career. But it is also my opportunity to get better and better.'' Second-place honors went to Marco Rizzi of Italy. He won $16,000. Ivan Chan of the United States won third-place and $10,000. Virginie Robilliard of France placed fourth, David Kim of the United States was fifth and Martin Beaver of Canada was sixth. Brazilian Blumita Singer was disqualified Sept. 4 for allegedly falsifying her credentials. Judges questioned her ability to play the composition she submitted on an audition tape. Singer last week denied any wrongdoing and blamed her poor performance on the competition's social schedule, which she said did not allow her enough time to rehearse. She claimed she was disqualified to create a scandal to promote the event.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Bargainers Find Air Base Is Not Airtight
DOC.TEXT: White House and congressional budget negotiators are finding that when it comes to an impregnable sanctuary, Andrews Air Force Base is no Fort Knox. After a yearlong budget stalemate, negotiators decided that the Maryland airfield - just outside the capital - would be a good place for them to quickly piece together a package of tax increases and spending cuts for next year. There would be no competing meetings to attend. It would provide a chance to spend long, uninterrupted hours together to develop a camaraderie that could speed the way to a deal. And perhaps best of all, no meddling reporters or lobbyists who could pry out embarrassing proposals. It hasn't quite worked out that way. The bargaining, which began Sept. 7 and was supposed to last three or four days, resumed late Sunday for a ninth day, with no end in sight. Two officials, demanding anonymity, said the meeting was contentious as Democrats backed away from about $30 billion in cuts the two sides had been discussing in Medicare, agriculture and other benefit programs. ``It doesn't look good right now,'' one official said. The talks subsequently broke up the evening shortly before 10 p.m. and were to resume Monday at 10 a.m. On NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program Sunday, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said they hoped a deal could be arranged by Monday night. ``It's tough going, but I think tomorrow night we may well see'' an agreement, Foley said. In addition, important details of offers, counteroffers and agreements have been routinely reported in the press, causing bickering among negotiators over how the information was disclosed. The cloak of secrecy the participants have sought has been pierced so badly that the unlisted phone number of the Republican staff's fax machine at Andrews had to be changed last week because it was being flooded by messages from lobbyists. In other instances, congressional aides have asked reporters for information about the talks. Frustration by many bargainers with the leaks reached a peak Friday. That was the day news articles reported on a GOP tax proposal made at the negotiations. The articles noted that according to the non-partisan Joint Tax Committee of Congress, the Republican plan would boost taxes for low- and middle-income people and lower them for the better off. ``Don't burden an already difficult ship with this kind of thing or it will sink,'' Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., one of several negotiators who took to the Senate floor to complain, warned his Democratic counterparts. Just three days earlier, Domenici had kinder things to say about the Andrews talks. ``I don't think we could do it if we weren't somewhere like that,'' the senator said Tuesday when asked if the selection of Andrews was working out. Not only is information getting out, but pressure from interest groups is getting in. The negotiators last week were considering a plan to raise revenues by increasing the monthly Medicare premium for medical coverage - now $28.60 monthly - for people with higher incomes. But as the powerful senior citizens' lobby geared up, Democrats by week's end were said to have backed away from the idea, according to officials speaking only on condition of anonymity. The bargainers had wished that by meeting in seclusion, the two sides would be willing to propose dramatic tax boosts or spending slashes that they would be reluctant to offer publicly. They still hope that if a deal is reached, Democrats and Republicans alike would claim authorship and thus provide each other with political cover. But in some instances, the system has broken down. Last week, for example, it was reported that the negotiators were considering boosting the 16-cent-per-pack cigarette tax, perhaps doubling it. One official said the idea had come from Rep. Bill Archer, R-Texas, one of the negotiators. Archer vehemently denied that and said the proposal had been advanced by a Democrat whom he would not name. At the negotiations the next day, Archer angrily accused another bargainer, Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., of telling reporters that the tobacco levy was Archer's idea, which Sasser denied, said another official who also demanded anonymity. To prevent incidents like that, the negotiators have taken extraordinary steps to keep reporters at arms length. With the talks being held in the Andrews' officers' club, reporters have been confined to a press center on the base, about two miles away. They have been warned to not go near the officers' club, and on many occasions have not been allowed onto the base or out of the press center without an armed military escort. Many journalists are simply covering the talks from their offices in the capital, about 10 miles away.

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopian Jews Demonstrate To Demand Family Reunification
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Ethiopian Jews, many of them crying, demonstrated outside Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's office on Sunday to demand that the government help bring out family members stranded in Addis Ababa. ``We want our families. We want our parents. ... Mother! Father! Where is my mother? Where is my father?'' the crowd chanted. ``We ask you, please save our families.'' Many in the crowd broke into tears as they shouted bitterly for relatives left behind in Ethiopia. The protest lasted for about three hours, and the demonstrators briefly blocked a major road near Shamir's office. Israel television said police did not intervene. Officials said the government was doing all it could to bring Ethiopian Jews to Israel. Ethiopian Jews have sought to escape from their land, stricken by war and famine, to a better life in Israel. More than 17,000 Ethiopian Jews live here. Some 15,000 to 18,000 Jews remain in Ethiopia after about 8,000 were airlifted to Israel in 1984 through the Sudan. The secret, U.S.-backed campaign known as Operation Moses was called off after three months when news of its existence leaked to the press, embarrassing the Ethiopian and Sudanese governments. The majority of those left behind have abandoned their homes and made their way to the capital, Addis Ababa, hoping they can escape on the direct flights to Israel initiated when the two nations resumed diplomatic relations in October 1989 after a 16-year break. But only about 500 immigrants a month have arrived since October, and Israeli officials have announced there have been no arrivals since July. Ethiopian Jewish activists in Israel say about 250 Jews have died since then of disease and hunger in Addis Ababa. They say their stranded relatives need medical help and blame the Israeli government for its lack of action. According to U.S. congressmen, Ethiopia's Marxist government is trying to force Israel to sell it advanced weapons for use against the rebels in the African country's civil war. Israeli officials deny these reports. ``The government of Israel and all the Jewish organizations that deal with the Ethiopian Jewry do everything in their power in order to bring Ethiopian Jews to Israel as soon as possible,'' said Absorption Minister Yitzhak Peretz, who later appeared at the rally. The Foreign Ministry issued a special statement saying that some 2,500 Ethiopian Jews have arrived in Israel this year. It said efforts were being made to transfer the rest of them to Israel ``with the help of Jewish organizations and many friendly governments'' in spite of what the ministry called ``objective difficulties.'' But Addisu Masala, a spokesman for the protesters, disputed these figures on Israel television, saying that only 1,000 people have come this year and that the ministry's numbers were ``unreasonable.''

DOC.HEAD: No Progress Reported in Brief Sunday Session
DOC.TEXT: White House and congressional budget negotiators meet a little over three hours Sunday evening, but reported no progress toward agreement as they geared up for what was expected to be a marathon session Monday. Sunday's session marked the ninth day of talks, with no end in sight. Two officials, demanding anonymity, said the meeting Sunday night at nearby Andrews Air Force Base was contentious as Democrats backed away from about $30 billion in cuts the two sides had been discussing in Medicare, agriculture and other benefit programs. ``It doesn't look good right now,'' one official said. The talks subsequently broke up shortly before 10 p.m. and were to resume Monday at 10 a.m. Earlier Sunday, On NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., both expressed measured optimism that a deal could be struck by Monday night. ``It's tough going, but I think tomorrow night we may well see'' an agreement, Foley said. The negotiators are working toward a goal of reducing the budget deficit by $50 this year in order to forestall $100 billion in automatic spending cuts if they are not successful. The negotiators were considering a plan last week to raise revenues by increasing the monthly Medicare premium for medical coverage - now $28.60 monthly - for people with higher incomes. But with the powerful senior citizens' lobby gearing up in opposition, Democrats by week's end were said to have backed away from the idea, apparently contributing to Sunday night's reported acrimonious session.

DOC.HEAD: Weakening Hurricane Marie Should Skirt Hawaii, High Surf Feared
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with hurricane weakening, likely downgrade to tropical storm status, revised winds speeds, location and predicted proximity to island. DELETES 3rd graf pvs, ```It is... to conform. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `To monitor...
DOC.TEXT: A hurricane with reduced top winds of 100 mph spun toward Hawaii Sunday, bringing the threat of high waves and warnings to stay off the beach. Hurricane Marie, was centered about 380 miles east-southeast of Hilo on the island of Hawaii Sunday afternoon, and showed more signs of weakening, the National Weather Service said. Sustained winds near its eye fell to 80 mph, with top gusts reaching 100 mph. The hurricane was expected to be downgraded to tropical storm status Sunday night once sustained winds dropped below 75 mph, forecaster Tim Craig said. Gale force winds, which range from 39 mph to 54 mph, extended 150 miles from the center of the hurricane. Waves kicked up by the storm were expected to reach Hawaii, known as the Big Island, late Sunday or early Monday, the weather service said. All ocean and beach activities along the southern and eastern coasts of Hawaii should be halted because of the high surf danger, Hawaii County Civil Defense Administrator Harry Kim said. Hurricane Marie, moving westward at about 10 mph, would pass about 70 miles off the southern tip of Hawaii on Monday if it maintains its course and speed. On Tuesday it would pass about 200 miles south of Oahu, the island where Honolulu is located, the weather service said. To monitor rising surf, residents along the affected coastlines will maintain a watch and report to Civil Defense officials, Kim said. The last major storm to hit the Hawaiian islands was Hurricane Iwa, which struck on Nov. 24, 1982 and caused $234 million damage, primarily to the islands of Oahu and Kauai.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic Nun Injured as Youth Gangs Break Up Pro-Democracy March
DOC.TEXT: Gangs of youths attacked peaceful pro-democracy marchers in a slum district in the capital Sunday, injuring a Roman Catholic nun and two other marchers. About 50 people took part in the march through the Albouystown slum district in south Georgetown. Nearly 100 young people armed with sticks, bottles and bricks attacked the group, forcing the marchers to flee into side streets for safety. It was one of three marches organized by a pro-democracy group, Guyana Action for Reform and Democracy. Sister Dooreen Rowtie, a member of the group's steering committee, received five stitches for a head injury after the gang members smashed the windshield of her car at the head of the march. ``It is clear that the incident was part of a planned operation as gangs of youths formed human barricades and suddenly launched an attack without provocation,'' she said. The youths took an amplifier, guitar, tape recorder and the nun's wristwatch and gold ring. Sister Dooreen later appeared at a rally in her blood-stained clothing. No arrests were made. Members of the reform group said they believed the gang members were supporters of the ruling Peoples National Congress party, which has held power since 1964 and must call an election by May 1991. The ruling party is to begin its election campaign with a rally in Georgetown at the end of this month. The Marxist opposition Peoples Progressive Party, one of the front-runners, began its campaign last weekend in anticipation of a December election date. Guyana, a former British colony on the northeast coast of South America, has a population of about 810,000, about half of whom are East Indians and the rest blacks.

DOC.HEAD: 2,500-Acre California Forest Fire Corralled
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 2 grafs to UPDATE with fire contained. Picks up 3rd graf, `Unless we...'.
DOC.TEXT: A 2,500-acre forest fire that sent flames lapping close to three Sierra Nevada towns was contained Sunday as rangers searched for an arsonist. The blaze in the Stanilaus National Park was contained inside fire lines by Sunday evening, and firefighters expected to have it under control late Monday. ``Unless we get some weird weather, we should have it under control. All in all its looking pretty good,'' said U.S. Forest Service spokesman Mike Brown. The fire broke out Thursday in a campground on the north fork of the Tuolumne River, about 130 miles east of San Francisco. Flames came within two miles of the towns of Mi-Wuk, Sierra Village and Sugarpine on Saturday. Accidental causes were ruled out, Forest Service spokeswoman Joan Leidenthal said. ``It's definitely arson,'' Leidenthal said, adding that investigators had a few leads to a possible culprit. Four hundred people evacuated as flames advanced were allowed to return home. About 2,700 firefighters were on fire lines. No buildings were lost or damaged. ``There was the potential to really burn a lot of structures, but we protected quite a few,'' Brown said. ``We just got lucky. The weather cooperated.'' Relatively cool temperatures in the low 80s and winds below 10 mph combined with normal humidity to slow the fire's spread, Brown said. Five firefighters were injured. Three suffered minor injuries, two suffered broken bones.The cost of fighting the fire was estimated at $1.9 million.

DOC.HEAD: Chief of Staff Says Israel Worried About U.S.-Saudi Arms Deal
DOC.TEXT: Israel's chief of staff expressed concern Sunday that the Bush administration's proposed multibillion-dollar weapons sales to Saudi Arabia could destabilize the military balance in the Middle East. Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron also said Israel was worried about events in neighboring Jordan, especially the recent visit of radical Palestinian guerrilla leaders George Habash and Nayef Hawatmeh. The Bush administration reportedly is preparing to submit to Congress a request to sell Saudi Arabia at least $18 billion worth of weapons, including F-15 fighter planes, helicopters, tanks and other sophisticated arms to bolster the desert kingdom's defenses against Iraq. The administration has already proposed selling Saudi Arabia $3 billion in new weapons, including F-15s, M-60 tanks, 15,000 rounds of armor-piercing anti-tank ammunition and 200 Stinger anti-aircraft missiles. Speaking on Israel radio, Shomron said the arms deal would give the Saudis ``a large quantity of weapons, which are also of the highest quality.'' ``From our point of view, giving such weapons ... to countries that are still formally at war with us is certainly not a recipe for stability,'' Shomron said. ``I hope this situation will be balanced in order to guarantee in the future our technological superiority and deterrent capability,'' he said. According to Israeli sources, Defense Minister Moshe Arens, who is now in the United States, plans to ask Washington for money to help Israel's defense industry develop weaponry, as well as for U.S.-made weaponry such as F-15 and F-16 fighter planes. Turning to the gulf crisis, Shomron predicted that Iraq might be able to withstand the lack of food and other goods caused by the U.N. trade embargo but not a shortage of spare parts for the army. ``It is easier to convince people that for the cause of a just, important war they should be content with less food or services,'' Shomron said. ``If this problem of spare parts for weapons systems, mostly advanced systems, does not exist today, it will soon become a serious issue.'' Shomron said Israel was concerned about developments in Jordan because of its strong support for Iraq and the reappearance of radical Palestinian leaders in the kingdom. Habash and Hawatmeh have been supported by Syria but are now reportedly moving their headquarters to Iraq. ``Securing the border between us and Jordan is mostly under the responsibility of the Jordanian army, and there are many Palestinians in it too,'' Shomron noted. ``This situation carries many dangers; we are watching and we are alert to any possibility of a change.'' He reiterated Israel's long-standing policy that the entrance of Iraqi forces into Jordan would trigger a military response from Israel but qualified it, saying: ``I propose to remember ... that this is subject to consideration, to carefully determining what has entered, and for what purpose, but in principle this is a red line.'' ``We are preparing our forces for every eventuality, from the point of view of training, weapons and logistics,'' Shomron said.

DOC.HEAD: Forecast: U.S. Economy Will Dodge Recession Despite Mideast Turmoil
DOC.TEXT: Higher oil prices will hold down U.S. economic growth but the nation will not enter a recession this year or early 1991, according to a forecast by the Conference Board. The business group said in a statement for release Monday that the economy should grow about 1.5 percent in the current quarter and 2.6 percent in the fourth quarter of this year. But although the economy is expected to avoid a recession in coming months, corporate profits should slump and interest rates rise due to the jump in oil prices, said Gail D. Fosler, the Conference Board's chief economist. The board's forecast, anticipating a spot oil price of about $30 a barrel over the next two quarters, projects the federal budget deficit will hit $252 billion in fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1. The report says the cost of the mililary action in the Mideast along with the sluggish economy will add $20 billion to the base level of the fiscal 1991 deficit.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: U.S. Manufacturers Plan To Invest Same or More in 1991
DOC.TEXT: Three-quarters of U.S. midsized manufacturing companies contacted in a survey said they plan to spend as much or more on plant and equipment in 1991 as they did this year. Four out of 10 manufacturers with annual sales of $10 million to $200 million said they will invest the same amount next year. An additional third said they will increase such spending. Only one in five plans to cut capital spending next year, according to the survey by Grant Thornton, an accounting and management consulting firm. Replacing plant and equipment was the most prevalent reason given for increased spending, followed by spending to boost productivity, Grant Thornton said. Those who said they will decrease spending say they either believe they have invested enough or that they cannot afford more investments due to poor earnings or insufficient funds. The telephone survey was conducted in late June by the research organization Wirthlin Group, which randomly contacted 250 midsized manufacturers. Grant Thornton said the sampling margin of error was plus or minus 6 percentage points.
